direction.raw_text: The conjunction of an immense military establishment and a large arms industry is new in the American experience.  The total influence - economic, political, even spiritual - is felt in every city, every statehouse, every office of the Federal Government... In the councils of government we must guard against the acquisition of unwarranted influence, whether sought or unsought, by the military industrial complex. The potential for the disastrous rise of misplaced power exists and will persist... We must never let the weight of this combination endanger our liberties or democratic processes.  We should take nothing for granted...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: School kids reciting the Pledge of Allegiance.  WPA films of farmers harvesting the Texas plains.  Rain, thunderheads, a dusty car coming from far away on a road moving towards Dallas.  Cowboys round up the cattle.  Young marrieds in a church.  Hillsides of tract homes going up.  The American breadbasket, the West.  Over this we hear Eisenhower's address.  As we move into the election campaign of 1960, we see the TV debates, Nixon vs. Kennedy, Mayor Daley, Kennedy victorious... Against this is juxtaposed other forces: segregation, J. Edgar Hoover, military advisors, Castro, Marilyn Monroe, Lumumba... three frames of the Zapruder film counter-cut... ending with the Kennedy inauguration and the irony of Earl Warren administering the oath as he will Kennedy's eulogy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: November, 1960 - Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts wins one of the narrowest election victories in American history over the Vice- President Richard Nixon by a little more than 100,000 votes.  Rumors abound that he stole the election in Illinois through the Democratic political machine of Mayor Daley... (inauguration shots) At his inauguration, at a time when American males all wore hats, he let his hair blow free in the wind. Alongside his beautiful and elegant wife of French origin, Jacqueline Bouvier, J.F.K. is the symbol of the new freedom of the 1960's, signifying change and upheaval to the American public, scaring many and hated passionately by some.  To win the election and to appease their fears, Kennedy at first takes a tough Cold War stance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The beach, the bombardment, the rounding up of prisoners, Kennedy's public apology, Allen Dulles standing next to J.F.K., both uncomfortable with the small talk...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He inherits a secret war against the Communist Castro dictatorship in Cuba, a war run by the CIA and angry Cuban exiles out of bases in the Southern United States, Panama, Nicaragua and Guatemala.  Castro is a successful revolutionary frightening to American business interests in Latin America - companies like Cabot's United Fruit, Continental Can, and Rockefeller's Standard Oil.  This war culminates in the disastrous Bay of Pigs invasion in April 1961, when Kennedy refuses to provide air cover for the exile brigade.  Of the 1600 men who invade, 114 are killed, 1200 are captured.  The Cuban exiles and the CIA are furious at Kennedy's irresolution... Kennedy, taking public responsibility for the failure, privately claims the CIA lied to him and tried to manipulate him into ordering an all-out American invasion of Cuba.  He vows to splinter the CIA into a thousand pieces and fires Director Allen Dulles, Deputies Charles Cabell and Richard Bissell, the top leadership of the Agency.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Cuban rallies, footage of training camps, espionage activities, boats, cases of weapons, Robert Kennedy... John Roselli, Sam Giancana, Santos Trafficante, Richard Helms (the new CIA chief), Bill Harvey, Head of ZR/RIFLE, Howard Hunt...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The CIA, however, continues it's secret war on Castro with dozens of sabotage and assassination attempts under it's ZR/RIFLE and MONGOOSE programs - The Agency collaborates with organized crime elements such as John Roselli, Sam Giancana, and Santos Trafficante of Tampa, whose casino operations in Cuba, worth more than a hundred million dollars a year in income, Castro has shut down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Khrushchev, Kennedy, Castro on television, meetings with Cabinet, Russian vessels in Caribbean, U.S. nuclear bases on alert, civilians going to underground safe areas... the Russian ship turning around, the country smiling...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In October 1962, the world comes to the brink of nuclear war when Kennedy quarantines Cuba after announcing the presence of offensive Soviet nuclear missiles 90 miles off American shores.  The Joint Chiefs of Staff and the CIA call for an invasion. Kennedy refuses.  Soviet ships with more missiles sail towards the island, but at the last moment turn back. The world breathes with relief but backstage in Washington, rumors abound that J.F.K. has cut a secret deal with Russian Premier Khrushchev not to invade Cuba in return for a Russian withdrawal of missiles.  Suspicions abound that Kennedy is "soft on Communism."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Closing down Cuban Camps, McNamara speaking, Khrushchev and Kennedy, the "hot line" telephone system inaugurated, Kennedy with Jackie and children sailing off Cape Cod... Vietnam introduction, early shots, Green Berets, counterinsurgency programs, De Lansdale, leading up to the Test Ban signings... then J.F.K. at American University, June 10, 1963.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In the ensuing months, Kennedy clamps down on Cuban exile activities, closing training camps, restricting covert operations, prohibiting shipment of weapons out of the country.  The covert arm of the CIA nevertheless continues its plan to assassinate Castor... In March '63, Kennedy announces drastic cuts in the defense budget.  In November 1963, he orders the withdrawal by Christmas of the first 1000 troops of the 16,000 stationed in Vietnam. He tells several of his intimates that he will withdraw all Vietnam troops after the '64 election, saying to the Assistant Secretary of State, Roger Hilsman, "The Bay of Pigs has taught me one, not to trust generals or the CIA, and two, that if the American people do not want to use American troops to remove a Communist regime 90 miles from our coast, how can I ask them to use troops to remove a Communist regime 9,000 miles away?"... Finally, in August 1963, over the objections of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the United States, Great Britain and the Soviet Union sign a treaty banning nuclear bomb tests in the atmosphere, underwater and in space...  Early that fateful summer, Kennedy speaks of his new vision at American University in Washington.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of peace do we seek?  Not a pax Americana enforced on the world by American weapons of war... We must re-examine our own attitudes towards the Soviet Union... If we cannot now end our differences at least we can help make the world safe for diversity.  For, in the final analysis, our most basic link is that we all inhabit this small planet.  We all breathe the same air.  We all cherish our children's future.  And we are all mortal...
dialogue.name: dialogue

The President is wildly popular - except for the occasional posters calling for his arrest for treason...

dialogue.raw_text: More rumors emerge of J.F.K.'s backdoor efforts outside usual State Department and CIA channels to establish dialogue with Fidel Castro through contacts at the United Nations in New York.  Kennedy is seeking change on all fronts.  Bitter battles are fought with Southern segregationists to get James Meredith into the University of Mississippi. Three months after Kennedy submits a sweeping civil rights bill to Congress, Martin Luther King leads 250,000 in a march on Washington. Robert Kennedy, as Attorney General, for the first time ever vigorously prosecutes the Mafia in American life, bringing and winning a record number of cases - 288 convictions of organized crime figures including 13 grand juries against Jimmy Hoffa and his Teamsters Union.  The President also takes on Big Business, forcing back steel prices, winning 45 of 46 antitrust cases during 1963 and he wants to help everyday taxpayers by ending age- old business privileges like the oil depletion allowance and the fees paid to the Federal Reserve Bank for printing America's currency. Revolutionary changes are foreseen after J.F.K.'s assumed re-election in 1964.  Foremost in the political consciousness of the country is the possibility of a Kennedy dynasty. Robert Kennedy in '68, Teddy Kennedy in '76.  In November, 1963 John Kennedy travels to Texas, his popularity sagging to 59% largely due to his civil rights stand for which he is particularly hated in the South.  Texas is a crucial state for him to carry in '64.  With him is Vice-President, Lyndon Johnson and Texas Governor John Connally. On November 21, they visit Houston and San Antonio.  On the morning of November 22, he speaks in Fort Worth, then flies 15 minutes to Love Field in Dallas, where he takes a motorcade through downtown Dallas on his way to speak at 12:30 at the International Trade Mart.  Later, the motorcade takes him through Dealey Plaza at 12:30...
dialogue.name: dialogue

A young epileptic screams and suddenly collapses near the fountains in front of the Texas School Depository.  He has a violent epileptic fit that attracts surrounding attention. direction.raw_text: - NEW ORLEANS - SAME DAY (1963) Pause.  The lovely old china clock on the wall reads 12:35. Somewhere a car backfires.  We see a close-up of the clock moving to 12:36.  We hear the sound of a pen on paper, scratching... We see a shot of Jim Garrison as a young air pilot in World War II; hear the sound of airplanes.  The camera moves to framed photos of Jim as a young, Lincolnesque lawyer... we hear sounds of political rallies, cheering... a shot of Jim's grandfather shaking hands with President William Taft.  The sound of bulldozers carries us to a shot of Jim staring at piles of decaying corpses at Dachau... a photo of Clarence Darrow... a law degree and an appointment as District Attorney of the New Orleans Parish... Mother Garrison with young Jim on the desk... another family - his own.  We look across the thick desk with the chess set, A Complete Works of William Shakespeare and a Nazi helmet with a bullet hole in it... to Jim himself writing - pen to paper.  We sense the quiet intellect of the 43 year old man.  The clock ticks in the awful suspended silence. It's as if the air itself has been sucked from the silent room.  This is the last moment of peace before the World will rush through the door in all its sound and fury - to change his life forever.  The camera haywires into a close- up of Jim as he looks up... and knows. Lou Ivon, Jim's chief investigator, is already standing there in the room.  He is burly, in his 30s - his expression universal for that day.

direction.raw_text: The camera moves onto Jim with Liz and the children - Jasper, the oldest at 4, holds his dad's hand.  On Liz's lap, Snapper, the youngest, is asleep.  Virginia, the 2-year-old, is pestering the Boxer dog... and Mattie, the heavyset black housekeeper, 35, is in tears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (over the din) Did you shoot the President?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't shoot anybody, no sir.  I'm just a patsy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My god, he sure looks like a creep. What's he talkin' 'bout... a patsy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Oswald in front of the cameras, on a platform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oswald seems shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oswald looks over and spots Ruby in the back of the room, on a table.  Recognition is in his eyes.  The police start to move him out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim is moved by her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I was questioned by a judge. However, I protested at the time that I was not allowed legal representation during that very short and sweet hearing.  Uh, I really don't know what the situation is about.  Nobody has told me anything except that I am accused of, uh, murdering a policeman.  I know nothing more than that and I do request that someone come forward to give me, uh, legal assistance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you kill the President?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.  I have not been charged with that.  In fact nobody has said that to me yet.  The first thing I heard about it was when the newspaper reporters in the hall, uh, asked me that question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have been charged.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have been charged.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were you ever in the Free Cuba Movement or whatever the...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a voice in the back) It was the Fair Play for Cuba Committee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you do in Russia?  What happened to your eye?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A policeman hit me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He seems pretty cool to me for a man under pressure like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Icy, you mean. (shudders) He gives me the willies... come on sugarplums, it's past your bedtimes... (to Jim) Come on, let's go upstairs. (rises) Mattie - get ahold of yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, Mr. Jim?  He was a great man, Mr. Jim, a great man...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Texas D.A. Henry Wade addresses the journalists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim moves to the phone as Liz starts the kids up the stairs. The TV cuts to stills of Oswald's life.  Two newsmen sit in a studio, smoking, sharing information.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There is no one else but him.  He has been charged in the Supreme Court with murder with malice.  We're gonna ask for the death penalty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Newsman 7) So several hours after the assassination, a disturbed portrait is emerging of Lee Harvey Oswald. Described as shy and introverted, he spent much of his childhood in New Orleans, Louisiana and went to high school there.  After a stint in the Marines, he apparently became fascinated by Communism and in 1959 defected to the Soviet Union.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Newsman 8) He married a Russian woman there, Frank, had a child, and then returned to the United States after 30 months. But he is still believed to be a dedicated Marxist and a fanatical supporter of Fidel Castro and ultra left wing causes.  He spent last summer in New Orleans and was arrested in a brawl with anti-Castro Cuban exiles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Newsman 7) And apparently, Bob, Oswald had been passing out pro-Castro pamphlets for an organization called Fair Play for Cuba, a Communist front he reportedly belongs to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Newsman 8) And we have Marina Oswald, his Russian- born wife, who has identified the rifle found in the Book Depository as belonging to her husband.  And we have...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Kennedy's casket coming off the plane in Washington D.C. play under the newsman... Jackie stands there in her blood-spotted dress... we cut to the photograph of L.B.J. taking the oath of office earlier that day... and a still photo of Robert Kennedy's reaction...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (on the phone) Lou, I'm sorry to disturb you this late...  yeah, matter of routine but we better get on this New Orleans connection of Oswald's right away. Check out his record, find any friends or associates from last summer. Let's meet with the senior assistants and investigators day after tomorrow, Sunday, yeah, at 11... Thanks Lou.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - 2 DAYS LATER - DAY(1963) Jim is with his key players: Lou Ivon, chief investigator; Susie Cox, in her 30's, and efficient, attractive Assistant D.A.; La Oser, Assistant D.A. in his 40's, serious, spectacled; Bill Broussard, Assistant D.A., handsome, volatile, in his 30's; Numa Bertell, D.A. in his 30's, chubby and friendly, and several others.  They sit around a conference table with a black-and-white portable TV on a side table showing the current Sunday, November 24 news from Dallas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera moves to Lou Ivon, looking at paperwork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oswald was seen with him several times last summer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the TV we see the first image of the "backyard photos" of Lee Harvey Oswald holding the rifle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera moves back to the staff, who watch, obviously influenced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Members of the team exchange looks of surprise and disbelief.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (on TV) Lee good man... he not shoot anyone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As far as Oswald's associates, boss, the one name that keeps popping up is David Ferrie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know David - a strange character.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's been in trouble before.  Used to be a hot shot pilot for Eastern Airlines, but he got canned after an alleged homosexual incident with a 14-year old boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone, excited) Get Kohlman... he told somebody the Texas trip... yesterday mentioned to somebody about Ferrie... find it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These backyard photos were found yesterday among Oswald's possessions in the garage of Janet William's home in Riving, Texas, where Marina Oswald and her children are living. The picture apparently was taken earlier this year.  Police say the rifle, a cheap World War II Italian- made Mannlicher-Carcano, was ordered from a Chicago mailing house and shipped to Oswald's alias A. Hidell at a post office box in March, 1963. This is the same rifle that was used to assassinate the President.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That ties it up...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Another nut.  Jesus, anybody can get a rifle in Texas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hangs up) So it seems that Dave Ferrie drove off on a Friday afternoon for Texas - a source told Kohlman he might have been a getaway pilot for Oswald.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold your horses.  What kinda source?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grins) The anonymous kind, Chief.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I remember this guy Ferrie speaking at a meeting of some veteran's group.  Ranting against Castro.  Extreme stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We go back now to the basement of police headquarters where they're about to transfer Oswald to County Prison...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : The basement of the Dallas police headquarters - waiting.  Men mill around as Oswald is led out of the basement by two deputies.  Jack Ruby rushes forward out of the crowd - and into history - putting his sealing bullet into Oswald.  Total chaos erupts... The camera is on the staff, looking.  We hear gasps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim is silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see images of Oswald being lifted onto the stretcher, into the ambulance, and the newscaster crouching, whispering. Everybody in the room is stunned still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look to Jim.  There's a pause.  He is deeply disturbed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He's been shot!  Oswald's been shot!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn!  Look at that... Look at that... I don't believe this... Right on TV!  What is going on?  Who is this guy... oh Jesus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seventy cops in that basement.  What the hell were they doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jack Ruby... Who is Jack Ruby?  Oswald is hurt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, no trial now.  Looks like somebody saved the Dallas D.A. a pile of work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Well, let's get Ferrie in here anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NEXT DAY - DAY(1963) The portable television plays to Jim alone, sitting in his chair smoking a pipe.  We see searing images of the funeral - crowds of mourners, the casket being driven through the streets, the honor guards, the horses, the dignitaries walking behind, Jackie veiled... the faces of De Gaulle, MacMillan, Robert Kennedy.  We intercut briefly to Lyndon Johnson sitting down earlier that day with the Joint Chiefs of Staff... and then a future cut to Johnson in the Oval Office (staged). The shots are very tight, uncomfortable - noses, eyes, hands - very tight. As the door opens following a knock, David Ferrie is brought into Jim's office by two police officers and Lou Ivon.  Jim stands up, cordial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ferrie suffers from alopecia, a disease that has removed all his body hair, and he looks like a Halloween character - penciled eyebrows, one higher than the other, a scruffy reddish wig pasted on askew with glue, thrift store clothing. His eyes, however, are swift and cunning, his smile warm, inviting itself, his demeanor hungry to please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ferrie glimpses the low-volumed TV - and images of the funeral.  He looks away, jittery, and takes out a cigarette. Sharon brings the coffee in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lou and the two cops escort Ferrie out of the office as Jim turns to the television image of Kennedy's final moments of rest.  The bugler plays taps.  John Jr., 3 years old, in an image which will become famous, salutes his Dad farewell. The riderless horse stands lonely against the Washington sky.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Chief... David Ferrie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes hands) Come in, Dave.  Have a seat, make yourself comfortable.  Coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you remember me, Mr. Garrison?  I met you on Carondolet Street right after your election.  I congratulated you, remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How could I forget?  You make quite a first impression. (on intercom) Sharon, could you please bring us some coffee? (Ferrie laughs; pause) I've heard over the years you're quite a first-rate pilot, Dave. Legend has it you can get in and out of any field, no matter how small... (Jim points to the pictures on his wall) I'm a bit of a pilot myself, you know.  Flew grasshoppers for the field artillery in the war.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you mind if I smoke, Mr. Garrison?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (holds up his pipe) How could I?  Dave, as you know, President Kennedy was assassinated on Friday.  A man named Lee Harvey Oswald was arrested as a suspect and then was murdered yesterday by a man named Jack Ruby. (on each name, watching Ferrie's reaction) We've heard reports that Oswald spent the summer in New Orleans and we've been advised you knew Oswald pretty well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not true.  I never met anybody named Oswald.  Anybody who told you that has to be crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you are aware, he served in your Civil Air Patrol unit when he was a teenager.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... if he did, I don't remember him.  There were lots of kids in and out... y'know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hands him a current newspaper) I'm sure you've seen this.  Perhaps you knew this man under another name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I never saw him before in my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well that must've been mistaken information we got.  Thanks for straightening it out for us. (puffs on pipe, Ferrie looks relieved; images of the funeral continue on the TV) There is one other matter that's come up, Dave.  We were told you took a trip to Texas shortly after the assassination of Friday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, now that's true.  I drove to Houston.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was so appealing about Houston?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hadn't been there ice skating in many years, and I had a couple of young friends with me, and we decided we wanted to go ice skating.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dave, may I ask why the urge to go ice skating in Texas happened to strike you during one of the most violent thunderstorms in recent memory?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, it was just a spur of the moment thing...  the storm wasn't that bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.  And where did you drive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We went straight to Houston, and then Saturday night we drove to Galveston and stayed over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why Galveston?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No particular reason.  Just to go somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And then Sunday?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the morning we went goose hunting. Then headed home, but I dropped the boys off to see some relatives and I stayed in Hammond.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you bag any geese on this trip?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I believe the boys got a couple.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But the boys told us they didn't get any.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fidgeting, lighting another cigarette) Oh yes, well, come to think of it, they're right.  We got to where the geese were and there were thousands of them.  But you couldn't approach them.  They were a wise bunch of birds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your young friends also told us you had no weapons in the car.  Dave, isn't it a bit difficult to hunt for geese without a shotgun?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, now I remember, Mr. Garrison. I'm sorry, I got confused.  We got out there near the geese and it was only then we realized we'd forgotten our shotguns.  Stupid, right?  So of course we didn't get any geese.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see. (stands up) Dave thank you for your time.  I'm sorry it has to end inconveniently for you, but I'm going to have you detained for further questioning by the FBI.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaken) Why?  What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dave, I find your story simply not believable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NEW ORLEANS - NEXT DAY(1963) At a small press conference, the FBI spokesman reads a statement.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, this afternoon the FBI released David W. Ferrie of New Orleans.  After extensive questioning and a thorough background check, the Bureau found no evidence that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - SIMULTANEOUS WITH PREVIOUS SCENE In Garrison's office see the same broadcast, on the portable television.  Lou, Broussard, Numa and Jim watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lou looks at Jim, angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches to turn off the TV and get back to work.  The last image on the TV is:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim flicks the TV off as the overture ends.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (on TV) ...Mr. Ferrie knew Lee Harvey Oswald or that he has had any connection with the assassination of President Kennedy.  The Special Agent in Charge would like to make clear that Mr. Ferrie was brought in for questioning by the District Attorney of Orleans parish, not by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.  The Bureau regrets any trouble this may have caused Mr. Ferrie...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In national news, President Johnson has announced the creation of a blue ribbon presidential commission to probe the events in Dallas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Correct me if I'm wrong.  I thought we were on the same side.  What the hell business is it of theirs to say that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pretty fast, wasn't it.  The way they let him go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They must know something we don't. (dismisses it) So, let's get on with our lives, gentlemen... we got plenty of home grown crimes to prosecute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Commission will be headed by Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court, Earl Warren, and is expected to head off several Congressional and Texas inquiries into the assassination.  On the panel are Allen Dulles, ex-chief of the CIA, Representative Gerald Ford, John J. McCloy, former head of Chase Manhattan Bank...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .C. - DAY(1966) We look down at the White House from the plane's point of view.  A subtitle reads: "THREE YEARS LATER."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking out the window) That's a mess down there, Jim.  We've bitten off more "Vietnam" that we can possibly chew. Jim, now 46, reads the front page of THE WASHINGTON POST which details the latest battle in Vietnam.  He sits next to Senator Long from Louisiana, in his 50's, who's drinking a whiskey.  They're on a crowded businessman's shuttle.  We see a close-up of a newspaper article about the Vietnam war: "more troops asked by Westmoreland."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stewardess brings more drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Russell looks at Jim quizzically and laughs.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INTERIOR OF PLANE SENATOR RUSSELL LONG

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) Sad thing is the way it's screwing up this country, all these hippies running around on drugs, the way young people look you can't tell a boy from a girl anymore.  I saw a girl the other day, she was pregnant - you could see her whole belly, and you know what she painted on it? "Love Child."  It's fuckin' outa control.  Values've gone to hell, Jim... Course it figures when you got somebody like that polecat Johnson in the White House.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sometimes feel things've gone downhill since John Kennedy was killed, Senator.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't get me started on that.  Those Warren Commission fellows were pickin' gnat shit out of pepper.  No one's gonna tell me that kid did the shooting job he did from that damned bookstore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here you go, Senator Long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) I thought the FBI test-fired the rifle to make sure it could be done?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, three experts and not one of them could do it!  They're telling us Oswald got off three shots with world-class precision from a manual bolt action rifle in less than six seconds - and accordin' to his Marine buddies he got Maggie's drawers - he wasn't any good.  Average man would be lucky to get two shots off, and I tell ya the first shot would always be the best.  Here, the third shot's perfect.  Don't make sense.  And then they got that crazy bullet zigzagging all over the place so it hits Kennedy and Connally seven times. One "pristine" bullet?  That dog don't hunt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, something always bothered me about that from day one, and I can't put my finger on it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I were investigatin', I'd round up the 100 best riflemen in the world and find out which ones were in Dallas that day.  You been duck hunting?  I think Oswald was a good old-fashioned decoy.  What'd he say?  "I'm just a patsy."  Out of the mouth of babes y'ask me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think there were other men involved, Russell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell, you're the District Attorney. You read the Warren Report - and then you tell me you're satisfied Lee Oswald shot the President all by his lonesome.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Russell, honestly you sound like one of those kooky critics spreading paranoia like prairie fire.  I just can't believe the Chief Justice of the United States would put his name on something that wasn't true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the stewardess) Honey, another one of these.  This one's as weak as cricket pee-pee. Yessir, you mark my words, Jim, Vietnam's gonna cost Johnson '68 and it's gonna put that other varmint Nixon in - then watch your hide, 'cause there ain't no offramps on a freeway to Hell!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The study is lined with bookshelves up to the ceiling; we see photos of family, a chess set.  Jim, smoking his pipe, reads in a red leather chair from one of the 26 thick Warren Commission volumes piled all over the place.  Liz enters. Jasper, now 7, draws on a piece of paper on the floor at Jim's feet.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jim, dinner's just about ready... I've got a surprise for you... tried something new... Jim?  Jim, dinner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lost in thought) Mmmmm... sure smells good... but Egghead, do you realize Oswald was interrogated for twelve hours after the assassination, with no lawyer present, and nobody recorded a word of it?  I can't believe it.  A police captain with 30 years experience and a crowd of Federal agents just had to know that with no record anything that Oswald said would be inadmissible in court.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on now, we'll talk about it at the table, dinner's getting cold. (to Jasper) What are you doing in here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Daddy said it was all right if I was real quiet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising to dinner) Sure it is.  Freckle Face, if I ever handled a minor felon like that, it'd be all over the papers.  I'd catch hell.  And this is the alleged murderer of the President?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - (1966) Two-year-old Elizabeth watches "Crusader Rabbit" on TV as the new one-year-old sits in diapers with Liz at one end of the dinner table.  Jim sits at the other end.  There are five kids now, ages 7, 5, 4, 2 and 1... and Mattie, the housekeeper.  Dinner's finished, they pass plates, the children horse around... the boxer dog, Touchdown, begs for a piece of the action.  Jim, not a big eater, feeds him ice cream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Virginia and Snapper each get one of Jim's shoes as he dances with them, holding one with each hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the children dance, they fall off Jim's feet, laughing and giggling.  He throws each in the air and kisses them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liz comes over, smiling.  Jim takes her in his arms.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Again and again they ignore credible testimony, leads are never followed up, its conclusions are selective, there's no index, it's one of the sloppiest, most disorganized investigations I've ever seen.  Dozens and dozens of witnesses in Dealey Plaza that day are saying they heard shots coming from the Grassy Knoll area in front of Kennedy and not the Book Depository behind him, but it's all broken down and spread around and you read it and the point gets lost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never did believe it either!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (politely listening) Uh huh... Mattie, I'll do the dishes, you take Be up now.  And Elizabeth, too, your bedtime, honey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . Nahhhh!  I don't wanna go to bed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honey, that was three years ago - we all tried so hard to put that out of our minds, why are you digging it up again?  You're the D.A. of New Orleans.  Isn't the Kennedy assassination a bit outside your domain?  I mean all those important people already studied it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't believe a man as intelligent as Earl Warren ever read what's in those volumes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well maybe you're right, Jim.  I'll give you one hour to solve the case... until the kids are in bed. (rising, she puts her arms around him from behind and kisses his ear) Then you're mine and Mr. Kennedy can wait 'til morning.  Come on, everybody say goodnight to Daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (showing his drawing) Dad, look what I drew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) That's something, Jasper.  What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A rhinoceros.  Can I stay up another hour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dancing) Pickle and Snapper, my two favorite dancing partners.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight, my doodle bugs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight, Daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One hour, y'hear?  Some Saturday night date you are. (sighs) Mama warned me this would happen if I married such a serious man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, she did, huh?  When I come up I'll show you how Saturday night got invented.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The clock on mantelpiece reads 3 A.M.  Jim is alone, smoking his pipe. In the stillness, his mind crawls all over the place.  The camera closes on the thickly-worded pages of the Warren Report.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the Warren Commission hearing room in Dallas, 1964.  We hear thin, echoey sound as the attorneys question some of the witnesses. The overall effect is vague and confusing, as is much of the Warren Report.  A Mr. Ball is questioning Lee Bowers, the switchman in the railroad yard.  Bowers, in his early 40's, has a trustworthy, working-man face and a crew cut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim, upset, reads on... Another witness, Sgt. D.V. Harkness of the Dallas Police responds to a second attorney.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see another FLASHBACK - to the Dallas rail yards on the day of the assassination.  Three hoboes are being pulled off the freight by the Dallas policemen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I sealed off the area, and I held off the trains until they could be examined, and there was some transients taken on at least one train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Bowers... is there anything else you told me I haven't asked you about that you can think of?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing that I can recall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Witness is excused.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARKNESS Well we got a long freight that was in there, and we pulled some people off of there and took them to the station.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) You mean some transients?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARKNESS (V.O.) Tramps and hoboes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Were all those questioned?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dealey Plaza an hour or less after the assassination.  The three hoboes are marched by shotgun-toting policemen to the Sheriff's office at Dealey Plaza.  We note that they do not look much like hoboes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera's point of view is now from the railroad tower near Dealey Plaza.  We are fourteen feet off the ground, overlooking the parking lot behind the Grassy Knoll.  The shot includes this last car circling in the lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inside the railroad tower, Bowers glances out, busy with the main board, flashing lights, a train coming in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the parking lot from Bower's point of view - at a distance, but we have a sense of the cars and see the men at a distance, tow uniformed men.  The parking lot is bumper-to- bumper with a sea of cars.  Rain that morning has muddied the lot.  These brief images are elaborated on later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We feel the growing intensity: music, drums - but all blurred. We see a puff of smoke but no sound because of the window Bowers is glancing through.  A motorcycle cop shoots up the Grassy Knoll incline.  People run, blurring into a larger mosaic of confusion.  Bowers is confused, seeing this.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . HARKNESS (V.O.) Yes, sir, they were taken to the station and questioned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (astounded) And? (writes "incomplete")
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) (switching subjects) I want to go back to this Amos Euins. (voices dribble off)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Yes sir, traffic had been cut off into the area since about 10, but there were three cars came in during this time from around noon till the time of the shooting... the cars circled the parking lot, and left like they were checking the area, one of the drivers seemed to have something he was holding to his mouth... the last car came in about 7 to 10 minutes before the shooting, a white Chevrolet, 4-door Impala, muddy up to the windows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Towards the underpass, I saw two men standing behind a picket fence... they were looking up towards Main and Houston and following the caravan as it came down.  One of them was middle-aged, heavyset.  The other man was younger, wearing a plaid shirt and jacket.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There were two other men on the eastern end of the parking lot. Each of 'me had uniforms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the time of the shooting there seemed to be some commotion... I just am unable to describe - a flash of light or smoke or something which caused me to feel that something out of the ordinary had occurred there on the embankment...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: with Jim's heart pounding as he reads. Back in Dealey Plaza, S.M. Holland, an elderly signal supervisor, stands on the parapet of the railway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the scene from Holland's point of view - the puff of smoke lingering under the trees along the picket fence after the shooting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Four shots... a puff of smoke came from the trees... behind that picket fence... close to the little plaza - There's no doubt whatever in my mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jim is asleep, having a tortured dream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : We see the Zapruder film, in slow-motion and J.F.K.'s face just before he goes behind Stemmons Freeway sign.  Jim sits up suddenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liz stirs, shaken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes him now, gently, and pulls him down on top of her and kisses him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Honey, you all right? (looks at watch)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's incredible, honey - the whole thing.  A Lieutenant Colonel testifies that Lee Oswald was given a Russian language exam as part of his Marine training only a few months before he defects to the Soviet Union.  A Russian exam!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sitting up, angered) I cannot believe this.  It's four- thirty, Jim Garrison.  I have five children are gonna be awake in another hour and ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honey, in all my years in the service I never knew a single man who was given a Russian test.  Oswald was a radar operator.  He'd have about as much use for Russian as a cat has for pajamas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These books are getting to your mind, Mr. Garrison.  I wish you'd stop readin' them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And then this Colonel tries to make it sound like nothing.  Oswald did badly on the test, he says.  "He only had two more Russian words right than wrong."  Ha!  That's like me saying Touchdown here... (points to the dog) ...is not very intelligent because I beat him three games out of five the last time we played chess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gives up) Jim, what is going on, for heaven's sake!  You going to stay up all night every night?  For what?  So you'll be the only man in America who read the entire 26 volumes of the Warren Report?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Liz, do I have to spell it out for you?  Lee Oswald was no ordinary soldier.  That was no accident he was in Russia.  He was probably in military intelligence.  That's why he was trained in Russian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a quizzical look) Honey, go back to sleep, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddammit!  I been sleeping for three years!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you stop rattling on about Kennedy for a few minutes, honey... come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NEW ORLEANS - MORNING(1966) A Sunday, early.  We see a statue of Ben Franklin in an empty square frequented by drunks who doze on benches in a little leafy park in the center of the Square.  The camera moves to Jim by himself and then moves to a sedan, pulling up, which disgorges Lou Ivon and Bill Broussard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Morning, boys.  Ready for a walking tour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At 7:30 Sunday morning?  It's not exactly fresh blood we're sniffing here, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (points) Old stains, Bill, but just as telling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jim indicating 531 Lafayette Street, a seedy, faded, three-story building across the street from the square.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Remember whose office this was back in '63?  531 Lafayette Street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, Guy Banister.  Ex-FBI man.  He died couple years ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the exterior of the Banister Office on a day in 1963.  The door is now clearly labelled "W. GUY BANISTER, INC. INVESTIGATORS."  It opens and Banister comes out in slow motion, neatly dressed, rose in his lapel - the same office and same man we saw three years before when he pistol- whipped Jack Martin.  Banister seems to be smiling right at us, greeting us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back to the Lafayette Square of 1966.  Jim walks Ivon and Bill to the corner, to another entrance to the same building - this one with a sign that says "544 Camp Street."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill studies the present sign: "Crescent City Dental Laboratory", and gives Jim a puzzled look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lou gets it and glances up.  We FLASHBACK TO the exterior of 544 Camp Street in 1963.  Lee Oswald comes out the door into a full close-up, now clearly seen by us, and heads out into the street as Guy Banister intercepts him on the sidewalk, holding a leaflet and point to "544 Camp Street stamped on it.  Guy seems miffed at Oswald, tells him something quickly, and then moves on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Headed the Chicago office.  When he retired he became a private eye here. I used to have lunch with him.  John Birch Society, Minutemen, slightly to the right of Attila the Hun. Used to recruit college students to infiltrate radical organizations on campus.  All out of this office. Now come around here, take a look at this...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Camp Street.  Same building as 531 Lafayette, right... but different address and different entrances both going to the same place - the offices on the second and third floors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Guess who used this address?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (under) See this?  What the hell is this doing on this piece of paper? (he moves away) Asshole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) My God!  Lee Harvey Oswald.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Bull's-eye.  How do we know he was here?  Cause this office address was stamped on the pro-Casto leaflets he was handing out in the summer of '63 down on Canal street.  They were the same leaflets that were found in his garage in Dallas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to Canal Street in New Orleans on a summer day in 1963.  Oswald, in a thin tie and white short-sleeved shirt, and wearing a homemade placard reading "Hands Off Cuba"; "Viva Fidel!", is hawking leaflets to pedestrians with two young helpers. A large white-haired businessman in a white suit, very distinguished, walks with a friend on Canal Street.  Oswald glances at him and meets his eyes.  The businessman enters an office building.  This man is Clay Bertrand, later known as Clay Shaw. Some Cubans, led by Carols Bringuier, now appear.  One of them, "the Bull", is heavy-set with dark glasses.  More of him will also be seen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carlos throws Oswald's leaflets in the air and pulls off his glasses, prepared to fight.  Oswald only smiles, and puts his arms down in an X of passivity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no real fight, but the police, as if pre-alerted, arrive. Arrests are made.  We see Oswald in a room in the police station, talking with FBI Agent John Quigley.  A calendar on the wall shows that it's August, 1963.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a television studio in 1963, Oswald debates Carlos Bringuier with two moderators.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back in 1966, Jim walks with his two assistants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the Post Office building across the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim makes a gesture encompassing the whole Square.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He was arrested that day for fighting with some anti-Castro Cubans... but actually he had contacted them a few days earlier as an ex-Marine trying to join the anti-Castro crusade. When they heard he was now pro-Castro, they paid him a visit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (haranguing passerby) He's a traitor, this man!  Don't believe a word he tells you! (to Oswald) You sonofabitch, you liar, you're a Communist, go back to Moscow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Carlos, if you want to hit me, hit me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) There was no real fight and the arresting Lieutenant later said he felt it was a staged incident.  In jail, Oswald asked to talk to Special Agent John Quigley of the FBI who showed up immediately.  They have a private session.  Oswald is released and Quigley destroys his notes from the interview.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But the arrest gets him a lot of publicity and as a result Oswald appears on a local TV debate that established his credentials as a Communist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you're a Communist, are you not, and you defected to Russia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I am not a Communist.  But I am a Marxist-Leninist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you do when you were in Russia?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (defensive) I worked while I was there.  I was always under the protection of... that is to say, I was not under the protection of the U.S. Government.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell's a Communist like Lee Oswald doing working out of Banister's?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Y'ever heard of a double agent, Bill? I'm beginning to doubt Oswald was ever a Communist... after the arrest, 544 Camp Street never appeared on the pamphlets again.  Now here's another one for you:  What would you say if I told you Lee Oswald had been trained in the Russian language when he was a Marine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd say he was probably getting intelligence training.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lou, you were in the Marines.  Who would be running that training?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Office of Naval Intelligence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take a look across the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Post Office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Upstairs.  In 1963 that was the Office of Naval Intelligence - And just by coincidence, Banister, before he was FBI, was ONI.  What do they say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Once ONI, always ONI"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, he likes to work near his old pals.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bill, Lou, we're standing in the heart of the United States Government's intelligence community in New Orleans.  That's the FBI there, the CIA, Secret Service, ONI.  Doesn't this seem to you a rather strange place for a Communist to spend his spare time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you driving at, boss?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're going back into the case, Lou - the murder of the President.  I want you to take some money from the Fees and Fines Account and go to Dallas - talk to some people.  Bill, I want you to get Oser on the medical, the autopsy, Susan on Oswald and Ruby histories, tax records...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lord, wake me, please.  I must be dreaming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you're awake, Bill, and I'm dead serious.  And we're going to start by tracking down your anonymous source from three years ago.  How did you find out Dave Ferrie drove to Texas that day?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A straggly group of people watch from the grandstands eating hotdogs and talking in small clusters.  The horses are running early morning laps.  Three men sit apart in the bleachers. A scared Jack Martin, three years older than when last seen, still wearing the Dick Tracy hat, sucks up coffee like a worm does moisture.  He has the red puffy cheeks of an alcoholic and deeply circled, worried eyes.  Bill and Jim wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I need is a little clarification about the night Guy Banister beat you over the head with his Magnum.  You called our office hopping mad from your hospital bed.  Don't tell me you don't remember that? Jack looks away and doesn't respond.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're not under cross-examination here, Jack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here's my problem, Jack.  You told me you and Guy were good friends for a long time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: More than ten years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And he never hit you before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never touched me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yet on November 22, 1963 - the day of the President's murder - our police report says he pistol-whipped you with a .357 Magnum. (Martin's eyes are fixed on Jim) But the police report says you had an argument over the phone bill. Here, take a look at it. (Martin looks at the report) Now, does a simple argument over phone bills sound like a believable explanation to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to the night of the pistol-whipping.  The camera shows Banister laying Martin's head open / the beating the humiliation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill looks at Jim.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head slowly, dreamily) No, it involved more than that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much more?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (waits) I don't know if I should talk about this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'd ask Guy - we were friendly, you know - heart attack, wasn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you buy what you read in the paper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have other information?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't say that.  All I know is he died suddenly just before the Warren Report came out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why did Guy beat you, Jack?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I guess now that Guy's dead, it don't really matter... it was about the people hanging around the office that summer.  I wasn't really part of the operation, you know.  I was handling the private-eye work for Guy when that came in - not much did - but that's why I was there... it was a nuthouse.  There were all these Cubans coming and going.  They all looked alike to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to Banister's office in 1963.  There are Cubans in battle fatigues and combat boots; duffle bags are lying around.  David Ferrie, in fatigues, directs the Cubans as they carry crates of ammunition and weapons into a back room. Martin observes from another desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still in 1963, we see the exterior of Banister's office.  A dozen Cubans follow Ferrie downstairs into the street, and pile into several cars, duffels thrown in with them.  Ferrie drives the lead car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the cars cross the long Lake Pontchartrain Bridge and enter a remote guerrilla training camp.  Bayou and jungle are all around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the guerrilla training camp at Lake Pontchartrain in 1963, we see scenes of basic training - shooting, obstacle courses, callisthenics - led by Ferrie and other trainers.  Scattered among the Cubans are several white American mercenaries.  We catch a glimpse of Oswald and glimpses of several other men we will see again, in sprinklings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's night at the training camp.  FBI agents race up in cars in the middle of the night, swarming over the camp, rounding up the trainees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see FBI agents loading dynamite, bomb casings, arms 155mm artillery shells, etc. Back at the racetrack in 1966, Jim listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin hesitates.  We hear the rhythmic beating of the horse hooves and Martin sucking on the steaming cup of coffee.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dave Ferrie - you know about him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Was he there often?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Often?  He practically lived there. It was real cloak and dagger stuff. They called it Operation Mongoose. The idea was to train all these Cuban exiles for another invasion of Cuba. Banister's office was part of a supply line that ran from Dallas, through New Orleans to Miami, stockpiling arms and explosives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) All this right under the noses of the intelligence community in Lafayette Square?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Sure.  Everybody knew everybody.  It was a network.  They were working for the CIA - pilots, black operations guys, civilians, military - everybody in those days was running guns somewhere... Fort Jefferson, Bayou Bluff, Morgan City... McAllen, Texas was a big gun-running operation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Where is Banister in all this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Banister was running his camp north of Lake Pontchartrain.  Ferrie handled a lot of the training.  There was a shooting range and a lot of tropical terrain like in Cuba.  A few Americans got trained, too.  Nazi types. Mercenaries.  But Ferrie was the craziest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyway, late summer the party ended. Kennedy didn't want another Bay of Pigs mess, so he ordered the FBI to shut down the camps and confiscate the napalm and the C-4.  There were a buncha Cubans and a couple Americans arrested, only you didn't read about it in the papers.  Just the weapons got mentioned... 'cause the first ones behind bars would've been Banister and Ferrie, but I think the G-men were just going through the motions for Washington.  Their hearts were with their old FBI buddy Banister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like I said, a fuckin' nuthouse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And Oswald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally) Yeah, he was there, too... sometimes he'd be meeting with Banister with the door shut.  Other times he'd be shooting the bull with Ferrie.  But he was there all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything more specific, Jack?  It's important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Banister's office in 1963.  Banister and Martin shooting the breeze as the straight-laced middle-aged secretary, Delphine Roberts, hurries in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Banister just looks at her and laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back at the racetrack...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FLASHBACK to Banisters office on a day in 1963.  Martin is snooping in Banister's files.  Cut to Martin leaving the office as a big businessman with white hair briefly talks to Oswald and then goes into Banister's private office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Banister lets the man into his private office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martin picks his way nervously down the bleacher benches.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Yeah, one time the secretary got upset, I remember...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't believe it, Mr. Banister. Lee Oswald is down on Canal Street giving out Communist leaflets supporting Castro!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's okay, Delphine, he's with us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyone else involved at Banister's level?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) There was one guy, I don't know, big guy, business guy, white hair - I saw him come into the office once. He looked out of place, y'know - like a society guy.  Can't remember his name. (thinking) Oswald was with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He had something to do with money. I remember him cause Guy, who didn't kiss anybody's ass, sure kissed his.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clay something, that was his name - Clay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bertrand.  Clay Bertrand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah!  That's it. (pause, paranoid) I don't know.  Maybe it wasn't.  I gotta go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bill) Clay Bertrand.  He's in the Warren Report.  He tried to get Oswald a lawyer. (to Martin) Was Kennedy ever discussed, Jack?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.  'Course they hated the sonofabitch, but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The assassination, Jack?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tightens) Never.  Not with me sir, never... Listen, I think I'd better go.  I said enough.  I said all I'm going to say. (rises suddenly)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold on, Jack.  What's the problem?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the problem?  What's the problem?  Do I need to spell it out for you, Mr. Garrison?  I better go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody knows what we're talking about, Jack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're so naive, mister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - FRENCH QUARTER - DAY(1966) Jim drives, with Numa in the front and Bill in the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim pulls the car over to park.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's a terrific yard, Chief, but the man's an obvious alcoholic with a reputation lower than crocodile piss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does that bother you, Bill?  I always wondered in court why it is because a woman is a prostitute, she has to have bad eyesight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'll never sign a statement, boss, let alone get on a witness stand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When something's rotten in the land, Bill, it generally isn't just one fish, we'll get corroboration... find this Clay Bertrand.  If I were a betting man, I'd give you 10 to 1 it's an alias.  Start checking around the Quarter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the six of us, with almost no budget and in secret, are going to solve the case that the Warren Commission with dozens of support staff and millions of dollars couldn't solve.  We can't keep up with the crimes in the Parish as it is, Chief.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The murder of a President, Bill, is a crime in Orleans Parish too.  I didn't pick you because of your legal skill, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gee, thanks boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But because you're a fighter.  I like a man who isn't scared of bad odds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jim and the others get out of the car and head towards Antoine's Restaurant.  A black woman greets him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She laughs.  Others move in on him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How ya doing, Mr. Garrison?  Remember me - from the piano bar at the Royal Orleans?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sure do.  We sang "You're the Cream in My Coffee."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Numa) Make sure we come back here, now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They enter a busy lunchtime crowd in an elegant eatery.  Lou Ivon and Al Oser are waiting for them as they're shown to their table by the Maitre d'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lou's been waiting, excited.  He gives Jim blowups of the five hobo photographs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera moves in on the photographs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Garrison, we have not seen enough of you lately.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Been too busy, Paul - an elected man can't have as much fun as he used to. (seeing Lou and Al) Welcome back, Lou.  Find out anything on those hobos?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They took 'em to the Sheriff's office, not the police station, and they let 'em go.  No record of them ever being questioned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't say that comes as a surprise anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A photographer from The Dallas Times Herald got some great shots of them never published...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the "hoboes" being escorted to the Sheriff's office - as per Sgt. Harkness' earlier description.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susie Cox arrives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How 'bout that railroad man, Lee Bowers?  Saw those men at the picket fence?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She talked to a cop from a hospital bed two days before the assassination, said Kennedy would be hit that Friday.  She said she was a dope runner for Jack Ruby and that Ruby knew Oswald for years...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...take a good look, chief, do any of 'em look like the hoboes you remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hoboes I knew of old used to sleep in their clothes - these two look pretty young.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...not a single frayed collar or cuff, new haircuts, fresh shaves, clean hands - new shoe leather. Look at the ear of the cop... That's a wire.  What's a cop wearing a headset for?  I think they're actors, chief; they're not cops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who the hell are they, then!  Hi, Susie, sit down. (to Lou) This could be it.  Let's start looking for 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Graveyard dead.  August this year. (Jim curses quietly) A single car accident on an empty road in Midlothian, Texas.  The doctor said he was in some kind of strange shock when he died. (pause)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shares the look) We need to find more witnesses, Lou.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There was Rose Cheramie.  A whore. Two Cubans threw her out of a car on the way to Dallas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can we find her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Graveyard dead near Big Sandy, Texas in '65.  Two in the morning on some highway.  A hit and run.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to Rose lying dead on an empty highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack Ruby's been rotting in a Dallas jail cell for three years.  Maybe he's ready to crack?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why not go right to the horse's mouth, chief?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we go to him our investigation'll hit the front pages by sunrise. Blow up right in our face.  Ruby was just given a new trial.  If he has something to say, it'll be there. Susie, what did you find out on Oswald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Negative on his tax records. Classified.  First time I know a D.A. can't get a tax record.  I put together a list of all the CIA files on Oswald that were part of the Warren Report and asked for them.  There are about 1200 documents... (gives it to Jim who reads) Oswald in the USSR, in Mexico City, Oswald and the U2, a CIA 201 personnel file, a memo from the Director on Oswald, travel and activities - can't get one of them.  All classified as secret on the grounds of national security.  It's real strange.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe there's more to this, Susie. The CIA's keeping something from our enemies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but we're talking about a dead warehouse employee of no political significance.  Three years later and he's still classified?  They gave us his grammar school records, a study of his pubic hairs... Put it in context, Bill, of what we know about Oswald.  Lonely kid, no father, unstable childhood, high school dropout - wants to grow up and be a spy, joins the Marines at 17.  He learns Russian, he acts overtly Marxist with two other marines, but he's stationed at a top secret base in Japan where U2 spy flights over Russia originate.  He's discharged from the Marines supposedly because his mother's sick.  He stays home 3 days, then with a $1500 ticket from a $203 bank account, he goes to Moscow...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Moscow in 1959.  We see shots of the city - strange and eerie black-and-white stills.  Inside the U.S. Embassy Oswald slaps his passport on the table with a formal letter.  Two consuls attend him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Continuing the Moscow flashback, we see Oswald talking with a female journalist in his small room in the Hotel Metropole. Again he sounds robotic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see photos of the city of Minks, in Russia, Oswald with various friends and tourists, shots of Lee and Marina with a new baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see documentary shots of the U2 on Russian soil... Francis Gary Powers... The Summit Conference canceled... Eisenhower and Khrushchev.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The screen shows photos of New York: Empty docks... a ship coming in... Wall Street on a Sunday morning - Graphic Weegee- type black-and-white stills, then a photo of Spas T. Raikin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (voice stilted) I want to renounce my citizenship and become a Soviet citizen.  I'm going to make known to them all information I have concerning the Marine Corps and my specialty therein, radar operation...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) One of the consuls, John McVickar, says Oswald's performance was not spontaneous - it seemed coached. Oswald gives an interview to a journalist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will never return to the United States for any reason.  It is a capitalist country, an exploitive, racist country.  I am a Marxist since I was 15.  I've seen poor niggers and that was a real lesson.  People hate because they're told to hate, like school kids.  It's the fashion to hate people in the U.S.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The Russians are skeptical - want to send him back.  Maybe they suspect he's a spy.  He supposedly slashes his wrists in a suicide attempt so that they're forced to keep him, and he disappears for six weeks, presumably with the KGB.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finally they shuttle him to a radio factory in Minks where he lives as high on the hog as he ever has - he's given 5,000 rubles, a roomy apartment with a balcony, has affairs with local girls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Makes sense - he's a spokesman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he never writes, speaks, or does any propaganda for the Russians.  He meets Marina, whose uncle is a colonel in Soviet intelligence, at a trade union dance; she thinks he's Russian the way he speaks, six weeks later they marry, have a daughter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't someone say he didn't speak good Russian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a contradiction, Numa, get used to them.  The only explanation for the royal treatment is he did give them radar secrets.  Or fake secrets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I don't know if it's coincidence, but Oswald had a top security clearance and knew about the U2 program from his days at Atsugi Air Base in Japan.  Six months after he arrives in Russia, Francis Gary Powers' U2 spy flight goes down in Russia.  That plane was untouchable. Powers hinted that Oswald could've given the Russians enough data to hit it.  As a direct result, the peace summit between Khrushchev and Eisenhower failed.  I can't help thinking of that book Seven Days In May, maybe someone in our military didn't want the Peace Conference to happen, maybe Oswald was part of that.  It gets weirder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Susie, you're an assistant D.A., remember.  Stick to what you can prove in court.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want facts, Bill?  Okay.  From 1945 to '59 only two U.S. soldiers defect to Russia.  From '59 to '60, seven defect, six return, one of them another Marine a month before Oswald.  All of them young men made to seem poor, disenchanted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't get sidetracked!  How does he get back to the States?  That's the point.  Does he have any problems?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: None!  The State Department issues him a new passport in 48 hours and loans him the money to travel.  He's never investigated or charged by the Navy for revealing classified information or, as far as we know, debriefed by the CIA.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is a man whose secrets cause us to change our radar patterns in the Pacific!  He should've been prosecuted as a traitor!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The FBI finally gets around to talking to him in Dallas and runs a file on him as a miscreant Communist type.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But who meets him when he gets off the boat in New York in June '62?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Spas T. Raikin, a leading member of an anti-Communist group.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And Marina?  Does she have a problem getting out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) None either.  It's bizarre.  It's next to impossible to get Russian sweethearts out.  Nor does Lee have any problem getting a new passport when he wants to go to Cuba and Russia in '63.  A man who has defected once already.  It's crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dammit, it doesn't add up!  Ordinary people get blacklisted for leftist affiliations!  The State Department did everything short of dispatching a destroyer to Minks to insure Oswald's return.  Only intelligence people can come and go like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a Forth Worth map factory.  We see Oswald at work on photo mattes with a Minox spy camera.  The camera shows close-ups of maps and then flashes to a hand in the photographic section.  We see a close-up of Oswald's head in a photograph - the same headshot that will be superimposed on the Oswald photo - and a razor blade cutting mattes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The next thing we know he's living in Dallas/Ft. Worth in October '62 working 6 months at Jaggars-Chiles- Stovall, a photographic firm that contracts to make maps for the U.S. Army... He starts work only days before the government reveals Russian missiles in Cuba and the crisis explodes.  Oswald may have had access to missile site footage obtained by the U2 planes and works alongside a young man who'd been in the Army Security Agency.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sort of like Benedict Arnold coming back to George Washington's cabinet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Equally incongruous is Oswald becoming chummy with the White Russian community of Dallas - all rabid anti- Communists.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Fort Worth in 1963.  In Oswald's cheap apartment, seven White Russians, including George de Mohrenschildt, a distinguished grey-haired man in his late fifties, are visiting Marina and Oswald, bringing old dresses, groceries, and toys and milk for the crying baby, whose cradle is two suitcases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Oswald and de Mohrenschildt talking with the others and a magazine cover with J.F.K. the subject of discussion.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: His closest friend is an oilman named George de Mohrenschildt who's about 35 years older than Oswald, who's only 23 and supposedly broke.  De Mohrenschildt is a member of the Dallas Petroleum Club, speaks five languages and was in French Vichy Intelligence during the War.  Also rumoured to have been a Nazi sympathizer and member of the "Solidarists", an international anti- Communist organization with many Eastern Europeans and ex-Nazis, many of them brought here by the CIA after the war, many of them involved in oil and munitions interests in Dallas and the Southwest.  You figure it.
dialogue.name: dialogue
