dialogue.raw_text: Where'd you get all this Nazi stuff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hands him a file) Read it.  They called it "Project Paperclip."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) This is the guy that keeps turning up in colonial countries and each time something strange happens. Coup d'etats, presidents overthrown. He shows up on a "walking tour" of Guatemala's Cuban invasion camps just before the Bay of Pigs invasion. If we don't know he's CIA, let's circle him very probable - Oswald's handler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think he's made some mistakes on Cuba, but he's doing a pretty good job.  If he succeeds, in my opinion, he'll be a great President.  And a really attractive one too - open features, great head of hair... (laughs)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) De Mohrenschildt draws a picture of Oswald as an intellectual, well read, speaks excellent Russian, a man who adored J.F.K.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's scenery.  Don't get sidetracked.  This is the man, bottom line, who nailed Oswald to the Warren Commission as a potentially violent man, and linked him to the rifle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Oswald's apartment on a different day in 1963. George de Mohrenschildt points out a Mannlicher-Carcano rifle in the closet, turns to Lee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lee's look is sickly.  He freezes up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So, Lee, what are you taking a potshot at this week - rabbits or fascists?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: scene of White Russian gathering in Oswald's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna Meller, one of the guests, glances at a copy of Das Kapital in a pile of books, and talks to another Russian man about it... Talking now to Lee and Marina are Janet and Bill Williams, a mid-American couple in their late twenties, freshly minted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Oswald and another man in the Texas School Book Depository in 1963.  They are hauling and stacking school textbooks - an obviously lower-level job for Oswald after the map factory.  We cut ahead to empty graphics of the sealed off area, the window site, the cafeteria.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the interior of the Williams' home in Irving on a day in 1963.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Marina and Oswald in bed at night in the Williams' house, in a tender scene.  Oswald says goodbye to his child.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The only Russian that suspects Oswald of still being a Communist is Anna Meller.  But her Russian friend tells her "he's checked" with the local FBI and was told Oswald is all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Oswalds are introduced by George de Mohrenschildt to Janet and Bill Williams.  It's through Janet Williams in October '63 that Lee gets the warehouse job, right smack on Elm Street at the Book Depository, which is owned by another oilman with ties to defense and military intelligence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Presumably so he can now exercise his intellect stacking school texts at $1.25 an hour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) All I can find out about the Williams' is their tax returns are classified and that Bill Williams, a descendant of the Cabots of Massachusetts, has links through his family and United Fruit to the CIA and does classified work for Bell Helicopter which requires a security clearance - so what is Oswald, a defector, doing visiting his wife in his house? Williams has a relationship at Bell with General Walter Dornberger, another one of the Nazis we brought in after the War for our missile program.  He used slave labor to build the V-2 Rockets for Hitler before Bell needed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wonder about the Williams'.  Just where did the first description of Oswald come from at 12:44?  No one knows.  They claimed it was Brennan's, but his description came after 1 P.M.  Who called?  Somehow the FBI's been tapping the Williams' and picks up a call between Bell Helicopter and Janet's phone, an unidentified voice saying "We both know who's responsible."  Who called?  Why's the Bureau been tapping them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) His wife, Janet Williams, studied Russian in college and her father worked for the Agency for International Development, which works hand in hand with the CIA. She suddenly becomes Marina's best friend.  Marina fights often with Lee about many things - his secrecy, the lack of money.  She says Lee is not sexually adequate.  Lee hits her on several occasions.  Bill Williams' convenient separation from Janet allows Janet to invite Marina to move into her house in Irving.  There Marina and Lee have a second daughter - while Lee, now 24, stores his belongings in Janet's garage and rents a small room in Dallas under an alias of "O.H. Lee".
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Oswald living in a boarding house.  It is at night, and he sits in his room alone.  The housekeeper, Earlene Roberts, heavyset, white, in her 60's, comes in and asks him if he wants to watch some TV with her.  He declines.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When he's arrested, Marina buries him with the public.  Her description of him is that of a psychotic and violent man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marina on TV, a different person from before.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I do not want to believe, but I have too much facts.. tell me that Lee shot Kennedy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Yeah, after, they take her to Six Flags Inn in Arlington, prepare her for the interviews, teach her how she should answer - and after two months and 46 interviews, she has a nervous breakdown. (flashback) Oswald was no angel, that's clear, but who was he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Antoine's Restaurant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see blank faces around the table.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm lost, boss.  What are we saying here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're saying that when Oswald went to Russia, he was not a real defector, that he was an intelligence agent on some kind of mission for our government and he remained one till the day he died, that's what we're saying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And therefore because Oswald pulled the trigger, the intelligence community murdered their own commander in chief.  That's what you're saying!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll go you one better!  Maybe Oswald didn't even pull the trigger, Bill. The nitrate test indicates he didn't even fire a rifle on November 22nd. And on top of that, they didn't even bother to check if the rifle had been fired that day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He had his palm print on the weapon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It went to the goddamn FBI and they didn't find a goddamn thing.  It comes back a week later and one guy in the Dallas police department suddenly finds a palm print which for all I know he could've taken off Oswald at the morgue.  There's no chain of evidence, Bill.  And what about the tow guns actually seen in the Depository?  One an Enfield photographed by a newsman and the other a Mauser, described by Deputy Weitzman... Maybe, just maybe, Lee Oswald was exactly what he said he was Bill - "a patsy".  Take it at face value.  Lou, Susie, I'm going with my gut here.  He's got an alias of Hidell to buy the rifle, "O.H. Lee" to rent the room, right?  What's in a name, right?  In intelligence, they're assumed to be fake.  A name is sort of like a postbox number, a code - several different people can use the same name, right?  Then why can't somebody be using Oswald's name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To frame him, obviously.  You got to get in your minds how the hell spooks think, Bill!  They're not ordinary crooks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never could figure out why this guy orders a traceable weapon to that post office box when you can go into any store in Texas, give a phony name and walk out with a cheap rifle which can never be traced.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unless he or someone else wants him to get caught.  Maybe he never ordered the weapon, Lou.  Somebody else did. It was picked up at the post office early morning when Oswald's time sheet shows him clocked in at his job.  Lou, come alive.  These things are not adding up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I still have to question what the legal basis is that supports this, boss.  Susie's stuff is colorful, but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's start making some assumptions about the man.  Why would he leave a path as big as Lee Harvey Oswald's? This is not a thin trail, gentlemen, it is a very wide one.  Who found the evidence?  Who set him up?  Lou, Bill, Susie, I want you to go back and check all the sightings of Oswald in Dallas, New Orleans and Mexico in the summer and fall of '63 - see if it's the same guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boss, Oswald impersonators?  Sounds like James Bond now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Al, you can't tell a mink from a coonskin unless you see the fur up close.  Goddamn, Sam!  If we don't start reading between the lines here! Y'all gotta start thinking on a different level - like the CIA does. We're through the looking glass. Here white is black and black is white.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think, Lou?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just an investigator, Bill.  I leave the theories to you lawyers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You, Numa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A week ago I would've said this is nuts, but now ... (shakes his head) There's a lot of smoke there, but there's some fire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you guys, come on.  You're talking about the United States Government here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're talking about a crime, Bill. No one is above the law.  Reduce it. A crime was committed.  Let's get to work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - JAIL - DAY(1966) Jack Ruby, thick fudge of an angry face, flu-ridden, confronts a doctor and two guards in his cell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ruby looks over at the two guards, who eye him.  The Doctor gives him the injection.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Christ, what the hell kinda needle is that?  I just got a cold for Chrissake.  I don't want any shot!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please relax, Mr. Ruby.  This'll calm you down and clear this up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doc, I'm telling you, I don't need any shots.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Ruby, I don't want to involve the guards.  It'll just take a few seconds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ruby's jail cell in 1964.  Ruby talks to men with their backs to us.  Lawyers and police clutter the cell, making Ruby hyper-nervous.  The chief official's white hair and avuncular voice are all we see and hear of him; his back is to us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ruby catches the stern face of Sheriff Bill Decker from the corner of his eye, the Assistant D.A. next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera pauses on Ruby's face.  The men rise and leave in the shadows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Then do you understand that I cannot tell the truth here?  In Dallas. That there are people here who do not want me to tell the truth... who do not want me to have a retrial?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Ruby, I really can't see why you can't tell us now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When are you going back to Washington, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks at watch) I am going back very shortly after we finish this hearing - I am going to have some lunch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I make a statement?  If you request me to go back to Washington with you right now, that is if you want to hear further testimony from me, can you do that?  Can you take me with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, that could not be done, Mr. Ruby. There are a good many things involved in that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the public attention it would attract.  And we have no place for you there to be safe, we're not law enforcement officials, and many things are at stake in this affair, Mr. Ruby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But if I am eliminated there won't be any way of knowing.  Consequently a whole new form of government is going to take over this country, and I know I won't live to see you another time.  My life is in danger here. Do I sound screwy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well I don't know what can be done, Mr. Ruby, because I don't know what you anticipate we will encounter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you don't stand a chance, Mr. Chief Justice, you have a lost cause. All I want is a lie detector test, and you refuse to give it to me. Because as it stands now - and the truth serum - how do you pronounce it - Pentothal - whatever it is. They will not give it to me, because I want to tell the truth... And then I want to leave this world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - (1967) Jack Ruby is escorted out of the infirmary, dead of cancer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - NEW ORLEANS - (1967) The puffy, smiling face of Dean Andrews, framed by huge black glasses, talks in a Louisiana hippie argot of the 50's.  The restaurant has a fancy French decor, mirrored walls, marble - it serves the cream of Louisiana society.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sudden FLASHBACK to Andrews' office on a day in 1963.  Clay Bertrand sits, back to us, talking to Andrews.  He has close- cropped white hair.  He is the same patrician man we've seen earlier with Oswald on Canal Street and in Banister's office. Andrews is evidently lying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim, in present, looking briefly - a pretty girl walking in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why you keep dancing on my head for, my man?  We been thicker'n molasses pie since law school.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because you keep conning me, Dean. I read your testimony to the Warren Commission and...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There you go.  Grain of salt.  Two sides to every coin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You tell them the day after the assassination you were called on the phone by this "Clay Bertrand" and asked to fly to Dallas and be Lee Oswald's layer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now that's pretty important, Dean. You also told the FBI when you met him, he was six foot two.  Then you tell the Commission he was five foot eight.  How the hell did the man shrink like that, Dean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They put the heat on, my man, just like you're doing.  I gave'em anything that popped into my cabeza.  Truth is, I never met the dude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what the cat looks like and furthermore I don't know where he's at.  All I know is sometimes he sends me cases.  So one day he's on the phone talkin' to me about going to Dallas and repping Oswald... (notices a woman, in present) Hey, pipe the bimbo in red.  What ever happened to that little gal you was dating in the Quarter - from Opelousas, y'know, elevator didn't go to the top floor but tits could smother gumbo with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (remembering) Yeah, she was pretty, all right, but not half as cute as you, Deano.  You shoulda tried a legitimate line of business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (chuckles) You can't ever say crime don't pay in Louisiana, Jim - only not as good as it used to.  Good chowder, ain't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When did you first do business with this Bertrand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bored) Oh, I first heard these street cats jiving about him back in '56, '57 when I lived down in the Quarter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Street cats?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Swishes.  They swish, y'know.  Young fags, you know.  They'd come into my bureau needing help, no bread, and I'd say, hey man, I ain't Rockefeller, who gonna back you up?  These cornmuffins go to the phone and dial...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Andrews' office on another day in 1963.  We catch a glimpse of a young swish sitting in Andrew's office talking on the phone.  Andrews is also on the phone to Bertrand, unseen, on the other end.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The dude on the other end says...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm Clay Bertrand.  Whatever they owe, I guarantee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, suits me fine, Daddy Warbucks - how do I get in touch with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And that's how I first heard of Clay Bertrand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) What was his voice like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You knew you weren't talking to some low life fag, you know.  He had command of the king's English.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did he pay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Always - like tits on a pig.  I wish I had a million of those bimbettes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And Oswald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (just a slight hesitation) Like I told to the Washington boys, Bertrand called that summer and asked me to help the kid upgrade his Marine discharge...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you saw Oswald how many times?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Three, four.  He came in with a few Cubano swishes one time I remember...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a third day at Andrew's office in 1963.  Oswald is in the office with two young boys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Andrews resumes eating his crabmeat Louie with gusto, Jim reaches over and grabs the fork in mid-air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Andrews puts down the fork, shaken, silent for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At a nearby table, a waiter has just poured brandy on Crepe Suzettes.  A blue flame hovers in the air as Jim leans forward across the table, speaking deliberately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Andrews stands suddenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Andrews drops his pink napkin in the crabmeat and waddles out.  Jim now feels closer to the truth than ever.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Recall any names?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in present) Mario, Jose - they wear names like you and I wear clothes.  Today the name is Candy, tomorrow it's Butsie. I wish I could help you, Jim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you speak to Oswald in Dallas?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (knee-jerk reaction) Hell, no!  I told this Bertrand cat right off, this isn't my scene, man. I deal with muni court, I'm a hack in nigger town, that kid needs a hot dog.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then how the hell did you get in the Warren Commission, Dean?  Except through the phone records in the Dallas jail?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nervous moment) There were no phone records.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course there weren't. 'Cause they disappeared.  And yet the Commission found you, Dean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know how they got to me. Maybe cause I repped him here.  The Feebees run background checks.  On my mama's breasts, man, that's all I got. (pauses, adjusts) There wasn't no conspiracy, Jim.  If there were, why the hell didn't Bobby Kennedy prosecute it as Attorney General, he was his brother for Chrissake.  How the fuck three people could keep a secret like that, I don't know.  It was Oswald.  He was a nut job.  Faggot, y'know, hated this country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dean, I think we're having a communication problem.  I know you know who Clay Bertrand is.  Now stop eating that damn crabmeat for a minute and listen. (gets Dean's attention) I'm aware of our long friendship, but I want you to know I'm going to call you in front of a grand jury. I took nine judges on, Deano, right here in New Orleans, and I beat 'em all.  If you lie to the grand jury as you've been lying to me, I'm going to charge you with perjury.  Now, am I communicating with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this off the record, Daddy-o? (Jim nods) In that case, let me sum it up for you real quick.  If I answer that question you keep asking me, if I give you the name of the "Big Enchilada", y'know, then it's bon voyage, Deano - I mean like permanent. I mean like a bullet in my head. You dig?  Does that help you see my problem a little better?  You're a mouse fighting a gorilla.  Kennedy's dead as that crab meat.  The government's still breathing.  You want to line up with a dead man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Read my lips, Deano.  Either you dance into the Grand Jury with the real identity of Clay Bertrand or your fat behind is going to the slammer.  Do you dig me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're just as crazy as your mama. Goes to show it's in the genes!  Do you have any idea what you're getting into, my man?  You think Jack Ruby just up and died of cancer in four weeks after he gets a retrial?  That's some kinda new cancer - I'd say that's a "going out of business cancer". You got the right ta-ta, but the wrong ho-ho.  The government's gonna jump all over your head, Jimbo, and go "cock-a-doodledoo!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - LOUISIANA COUNTRYSIDE - (1967) From the point of view of an approaching car, the prison looms over the swamp, dogs patrolling the wire.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) District Attorney Garrison to see Prisoner 5388, Ward Block 237B.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Send him on in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - (1967) A chief guard walks Jim and Bill into a circus-like atmosphere.  In Louisiana the prisoners can wear any outfit they choose, which makes this prison look like Mardi Gras. There are many transvestites.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie O'Keefe, a handsome, muscled, young chickenhawk with an earring, bandana, colorful clothes, an aura of burned truth in his intense, staring brown eyes and thick country accent, sashays over.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (with evident pride) ...we don't need no gates out there, sir, we got the "swamp".  Many of 'em gone in there but none come out... Hey, Willie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got some company, wants to talk wid you.  You behave now, boy, y'hear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the prison work area, where Willie talks, leaning against a tree looking out on a mangrove swamp.  It's lunch break and other prisoners move in the background, eating, socializing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I want to thank you, Mr. O'Keefe, for this time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call me Willie.  I ain't got nuthin' but time, Mr. Garrison.  Minutes, hours, days, years of'em.  Time just stands still here like a snake sunnin' itself in the road...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clay Bertrand, Willie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.  Clay.  I met him sometime in June of '62 at the Masquerade Bar. Dave Ferrie took me there, for the express reason to meet him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For sexual purposes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the Masquerade Bar in the French Quarter.  It's nighttime and Ferrie, Bertrand and O'Keefe sit at a back booth.  Bertrand, as seen earlier, is an imposing, white- haired patrician man, over six feet tall, heavily defined bones and eyelids, in his late 40's or early 50's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They rise to leave.  Bertrand with a slight limp.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Did he pay you for this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Twenty dollars each time.  Hell, it's no secret.  That's what I'm here for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Anything else unusual about him you'd be able to describe in a court of law, Willie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I remember he had some kinda thing wrong with his left leg.  He limped. Don't get me wrong, he's not one of those, you know, limp wrists.  He's a butch John.  You'd meet him on the street, you'd never snap.  You could go fishing with him, play poker with him, you'd never snap in a million years.  So one night we were over at Ferrie's place.  Having a party. Sometime in the late summer of '63.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dave Ferrie's apartment on a night in 1963. The place is filled messy bricabrac, including two dozen mouse cages for Ferrie's cancer experiments.  Ferrie, Bertrand, O'Keefe, and four Cubans in battle fatigues are laughing and fooling around.  Oswald is in a corner cleaning a .22 rifle with a scope on it.  He looks different, unkempt, unshaven.  A record player grinds out a speech in Spanish by Castro.  Some other people are there as well - it's a beatnik scene: sandals, hanging out, only one woman.  Ferrie is taking pictures throughout of the group horsing around, photographing Oswald.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ferrie separates them.  Oswald seems to resent an outsider being there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...there were about nine or ten people, Cubans, friends of Dave doing some stuff in the bush with him. Place was a mess.  Dave's mind was a mess, (laughs) Y'know he had all those mice cages around cause he's working on this cure for cancer... Dave's smart - real smart - speaks five languages, knows philosophy, medicine, military history, politics.  He wanted to be a priest but they defrocked him 'cause he was queer...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And that's where you met Oswald for the first time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Yeah, strange guy.  Dave introduced him as...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Willie, say hello to Leon Oswald.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over the racket) How ya doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sullen, to Ferrie) What the fuck's he doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck you, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to O'Keefe) Leon's in a bad mood, don't get excited, he's all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Would you say this "Leon" was actually Lee Harvey Oswald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in present) Fuck, yes.  Hell, I'm already in jail.  I got no reason to lie to you.  I ain't no nigger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on, Willie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (present merging to past) ...well the party got crazier and crazier, one of those, y'know "beatnik" type things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to O'Keefe) We're having a little meeting here. (indicates the second player) That's Castro.  Sounds like Hitler doesn't he?  Sonofabitch is going to go.  Real soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Muerte a Fidel!  Muerte!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritated at the noise) Oh, stop it already!  What are all these people doing here anyway?  I can't bear all this infernal noise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clara, don't be so sensitive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't come here for a pep rally. Get all this riffraff out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: later that night, when only O'Keefe, Ferrie, Bertrand, Oswald and three Cubans are left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oswald looks up, listens quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bertrand with his arms around O'Keefe, laughs, tries to change the subject.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oswald listens, playing with his rifle.  Bertrand suddenly turns cold, flashing a look at Ferrie.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...finally they got out of there and I found myself alone with Dave and this Leon, two of the Cubans, and this guy Bertrand.  Dave pulled out his clippings which he was always carrying around.  He'd been obsessed with Castro and Kennedy for months and he started in again...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (waving a clipping, drunk) Kennedy fucked us in '61, '62, and he's fuckin' us now!  And that fuckin' zealot Bobby Kennedy is the fuckee! The nerve of that little asswipe closing the camps.  Took all our C- 4!  Took ten thousand rounds, 3,000 pounds of gunpowder, all our weapons. Next we'll be living in a world where only the cocksucking Reds will have all the weapons and we'll be surrounded.  If we want a free Cuba, we gotta whack out the fucking beard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That faggot Kennedy won't let us. Our hands are empty - how can we kill him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (moving with a drink, walks with a slight limp) It's a real problem getting at him. Castro's got informers on every block.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing to a map of Cuba on the wall) Bullshit!  There's all kinds of new stuff.  I heard about rockets in an umbrella - they're tested at Fort Detrick?  I can show you a dozen poisons.  Stick it in his food, he'll die in three days, no trace.  We can put something in his beard, make it fall out, he'll look fuckin' ridiculous without his beard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drunk) Why don't we just take care of the main problem?  Which is that piece of shit Kennedy.  He's doing all kinds of deals!  Kissing Khrushchev's ass.  I wouldn't even call him President Kennedy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...then the Cubans left and the bullshitting was going on, Dave was drunk, really drunk and he starts in with Kennedy again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See, what Kennedy done, with him you should take a knife and stab and kill the fucker where he is now.  I mean it.  This is true.  But I tell you something.  I hope I get a week's notice.  I'll kill.  Right in the fuckin' White House.  Somebody's got to get rid of this fucker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, c'mon, Dave, you're never gonna get that sonofabitch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No?  It won't be long, mark my words. That fucker'll get what's coming to him.  And it can be blamed on Castro. Then the whole country'll want to invade Cuba.  All we got to do is get Kennedy in the open.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: David, David, always some harebrained scheme or another... Oh?  What do I see here?  Oooooh, let's have some more champagne, shall we!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interested in Ferrie's proposal) What about the Secret Service, the cops?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pacing, hyper) No problem if it's planned right. Look how close they got with de Gaulle.  Eisenhower was always riding around in an open top.  I know somebody who actually went up and touched Eisenhower once.  We need to have three mechanics at three different locations.  An office building with a high-powered rifle. Triangulation of crossfire is the key.  You get the diversionary shot gets the Secret Service looking one way - Boom!  You get the kill shot. The crucial thing is one man has to be sacrificed, then in the commotion of the crowd the job gets done and the others fly out of the country to someplace with no extradition.  I could do that myself.  I could fly to Mexico, and then Brazil.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't we drop this subject... it's one thing to engage in badinage with these youngsters, but this sort of thing could be so easily misunderstood. (he squeezes Ferrie)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ouch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I didn't think much about it at the time.  Just bullshit, y'know, everybody likes to make themselves out to be something more than they are.  Specially in the homosexual underworld.  But then when they got him (merging to the present) I got real scared, y'know.  Real scared.  And that's when I got popped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the prison work area.  Jim and O'Keefe continue talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he talks, Jim shares a sickened look with Bill.  Whatever truth he may be telling is necessarily compromised by an attitude that could be destroyed in court. GARRISON HOME - NIGHT(1967) Jim, Lou, Al, Susie, and Numa sit around the table having an after hours conference.  The kids run in and out of the room, playing.  Susie is doing the talking, showing new paperwork and photos.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Willie, are you willing to repeat your statements under sodium pentothal?  Under the supervision of a doctor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck, yeah!  I told you so.  And you can tell'em all I told you so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You realize the things you're saying, Willie, are going to be attacked by a lot of different people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bring on all the motherfuckers! Bring their college degrees in here! I got nuthin' to hide.  They can't buy me.  You can't buy me.  I don't even need the parole.  This is about the truth coming out.  You're a goddamn liberal, Mr. Garrison, you don't know shit, cause you never been fucked in the ass.  Fascism is here now, Facism is...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one's trying to buy you, Willie. It's important to know why you're telling us this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pauses) You wanna know why?  'Cause that mother fucker Kennedy stole that fuckin' election, that's why!  Nixon was gonna be one of the great Presidents 'til Kennedy wrecked this fuckin' country.  Got niggers all over the fuckin' place asking for their rights, where do you think we got all this fuckin' crime now, 'cause Kennedy promised 'em too damned much. Revolution comin'.  Fascism's coming back.  I tell ya this - the day that Communist sumbitch died was a great day for this country.  I jes' hate to think they're blaming it on some silly fuckin' Oswald who didn't know shit anyway.  People should know why that sumbitch was killed.  'Cause he was a Communist.  Put me on the stand, go ahead, I'll tell the same goddamn story, I'm proud of it, don't matter fuck all to me, things don't change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your hunch was right, boss, but it's even spookier than we thought. Starting in September '63 on, two months before the assassination, there are sightings of Oswald all over Dallas, buying ammunition, getting a telescopic sight fixed, going to rifle ranges... Early November, a Dallas downtown Lincoln- Mercury dealership where he tells the salesman Albert Bogard...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the Lincoln-Mercury dealership.  Oswald is deliberately kept in half or three quarter shots - a mystery figure.  He kicks the tires on a used red Mercury Comet, cocky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's take it out for a test drive. The salesman, Bogard, is hesitant.  "Oswald" doesn't look like he's got a dime to his name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the next scene we see the car, driven by "Oswald", zooming up the ramp and disappearing onto the freeway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Resume the scene at the dealership.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Oswald", unhappy, starts to leave.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, I got a lotta money coming in the next two weeks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...despite the fact he has no license and from what marina says, does not know how to drive, he hits the curves like Mario Andretti at the Indy 500. Bogard later told his boss he drove "like a madman."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Three hundred bucks down, Mr. Oswald, you can drive outta here with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who you kidding!  For this heap? Forget it...  No honest working man can afford a car anymore in the goddamn country!  Maybe I'll have to go back to Russia to buy a car...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ... really dumb dialogue like he's trying to draw attention to himself. A real moron.  He walks out.  The salesman remembers him as about 5'7", but we know from his draft card he was about 5'11"...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...several witnesses see him on several separate days at different firing ranges.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a Dallas firing range in 1963.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...one time, November 9, he decides he needs to practice on the target of the guy next to him.  Says something really dumb to the guy, who says Oswald was a great shot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, watcha doing, boy... that's my target.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, sorry, buddy.  I just thought it was that sonofabitch Kennedy, y'know.  I couldn't help myself. (laughs)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in present) ...about as subtle as a cockroach crawling across a white rug.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll go you one better, Lou.  He shows up at Silvia Odio's, a Cuban lady in Dallas working in the anti- Castro underground - remember that name, a solid witness.  The two Cubans introduce him as "Leon Oswald".
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the corridor of Silvia Odio's apartment in Dallas on a night in 1963.  Oswald drags behind two Cubans - one is "the Bull", heavyset with a scar over his left eye, who we saw at the Canal Street incident, and the other, "the Indian", is quiet and cold.  The men ring the doorbell and talk to a concerned Silvia as Oswald hangs back, watching, in the shadows.  The men give her intimate information about her father, who is imprisoned in Cuba.  The men chatter ad lib in Spanish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see a shot of Silvia on the phone in her apartment intercut with a shot of "the Bull" in a gas station phone booth, on a night in 1963.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silvia Odio is surprised to hear this information volunteered. "The Bull's" eyes are on "Oswaldo", outside the booth with "the Indian".  They're hanging out, talking to a mystery man, an Anglo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim looks at the famous photo... the camera closes in on a heavyset man who looks nothing like Oswald.  Liz has come back in and overhears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susie picks up the famous Life magazine cover shot of Oswald holding a rifle in his backyard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...the Cubans want Silvia, whose parents are political prisoners in Cuba, to help them raise money to assassinate Castro.  Something about the men bothers her.  She tells them she doesn't want anything to do with violence... about 48 hours later one of the Cubans calls her back...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on the phone, in Spanish) This guy Leon Oswald's great, he's kinda nut...  he told us we don't any guts, us Cubans, cause Kennedy should've been whacked after the Bay of Pigs, and some Cubans should've done that, it's easy to do, he says - you know he's a Marine, an expert shooter...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's like he's giving her information she doesn't even ask for.  She's scared, doesn't see them again till she sees Oswald's picture in the paper.  But the Warren Commission says she has bad eyesight because they have Oswald in Mexico at this time, trying to get back into Cuba. The Cubans think he's a double agent so they won't take him.  The CIA has a camera outside the Cuban Embassy and says this is Oswald in Mexico. (hands over a picture) You figure it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If this is Oswald, it must be our third Oswald.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The interesting thing is the extent to which the Warren Commission went to make him a Communist.  They got almost 150 pages and 130 exhibits of the report on this Mexico trip and the picture doesn't even match.  I'm beginning to think the point of the Mexican episode was to lay the blame at Castro's door.  If Oswald, or someone purporting to be Oswald, had gotten into Cuba, come back, then killed the President, the American public once again would've screamed for a Cuban invasion...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I even have doubts about this photo, boss.  It pretty much convicted Oswald in the public mind.  Well, according to Captain Fritz, Oswald told him during his interrogation the photo was fake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the Dallas Homicide Office in 1963.  Oswald is being interrogated by Will Fritz, Dallas Homicide Chief, who shows him the original of the photo from the Williams garage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see a blowup of the photo - the shadows, the crop mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FRENCH QUARTER - SAME NIGHT(1967) Broussard walks past a jazz wake leaving the cemetery - black flambeurs carry torches, people sing "When the Saints Go Marching in".  Bill is with a local gambler type.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's not me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It came from Janet William's garage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I never saw that picture.  It is my face, but my face has been super-imposed - the rest of the picture is not me at all.  I've done a lot of photographic work, and that picture was made by someone else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So who the hell are you?  Alex Hidell or Oswald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you're the policeman, you work it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in the present) Oswald, who worked for Jaggars-Chiles- Stovall, did know spy photography pretty well.  I took this picture to two experts.  Look at the way the shadows on the nose fall in a straight line like it's high noon.  But the shadow here on the ground reads like late afternoon or early morning. It's not the same time.  Also look at the crop marks across the chin. It seems like his head is pasted on somebody else's body implicating him with this rifle and gun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And of the two newspapers in his hands, one is Leninist, the other Trotskyite.  Any genuine Socialist would know they hate each other's politics!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clay Bertrand?  Sure I know him.  He comes around the Quarter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is he, Joe?  I've been to every bar, no one wants to talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told your uncle I never met a lawman who wasn't a punk.  You too, Bill, even if you're family.  He's a big shot businessman.  I seen him on the TV news a lot with all the other big shots.  A fag, you know.  Goes by another name down here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (excited) What's the other name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shaw.  Clay Shaw.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stunned) Clay Bertrand is Clay Shaw?  The guy who used to run the International Trade Mart?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, what's the big mystery? Everybody down here knows the guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So why does he call himself Bertrand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who gives a shit what he calls himself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: SUSIE ...now it gets positively spooky. In January, 1961 - in New Orleans, at the Bolton Ford Dealership - when the Oswald we know is in Russia - there is a man using the name "Oswald" to buy trucks for the Friends of Democratic Cuba.  The salesman never saw him again, but guess who's on the articles of incorporation of the Friends of Democratic Cuba?  Guy Banister. (reactions from the others) Banister has someone using the name "Oswald" to buy the trucks.  Hoover, at the FBI, writes a memo dated June, 1960, that there could be someone using Oswald's passport and identity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The staff members, anxious to go home, have all risen... and now sigh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all raise their hands as Bill walks in, excited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all stop, look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liz Garrison is the most shaken, as she pours a fresh pot of coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liz walks out of the room silent.  There is a tense pause.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn!  They put Oswald together from Day One!  Like some dummy corporation in the Bahamas - you just move him around a board.  Sent him to Russia, in and out, no passport problems.  You got the word "microdots" in his notebook, you got the Minox camera and the electronic devices they find in his possessions, the sealed DIZ201 personnel file.
