dialogue.raw_text: (incoherent) Oh, you got that?  Banister's pet project.  Getting paid by the government to work against the government.  Beautiful.  What a mind he had, what a guy, Guy.  He had all those files.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who was paying you, Dave?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think I was a getaway pilot for the assassination, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.  Were you? (Dave laughs) Who you scared of, Dave?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everybody!  The Agency.  The Mob. The Cubans.  Yeah, follow the Cubans. Check them out.  Here, in Dallas, Miami.  Check out a guy named Eladio del Valle.  My paymaster when I flew missions into Cuba - he's somewhere in Miami.  You're on the right track.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold it!  Hold it!  I'm not cooperating with anyone.  There's a death warrant for me, don't you get it?  Wait a minute.  You're not bugged, are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dave, I always play square.  No bugs. I'd love you to go on the record, but I"m in no hurry.  Whenever you're ready.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (checking the room) I don't have much time.  They don't even need bugs anymore.  They got these fuckin' satellite waves.  They put a bug in a friend of mine when he was born, right up his nostrils, subcutaneous, between his eyes.  He was one of those products of a crossbreading experiment.  A Nazi rocket scientist father and a Commie spy mother.  You'd never believe half the shit the Agency does. (holding his neck) I'm so fuckin' tired.  Haven't slept since that shit article came out. Why'd you guys have to go and get me involved with this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did we involve you, Dave, or did Clay Shaw?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That cocksuckin' faggot!  He's got me by the balls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Photographs - compromising stuff. And he'll use 'em.  The Agency plays for keeps... (checks the room for bugs) I knew Oswald.  He was in my Civil Air Patrol unit.  I taught him everything.  A "wanna be," y'know, nobody really liked him cause he was a snitch.  I treated him good.  He'd talk about his kid, y'know, really wanted her to grow up with a chance, but... He got a raw deal.  The Agency fucked him.  Just like they're gonna fuck me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me get this straight, now.  Clay Shaw is blackmailing you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuckin' A.  How do you think the Agency gets people to do their bullshit?  Fuck knows what they got on Oswald!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Room service.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was it the same Oswald, Dave, that was in Dallas, or was it an impersonator.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Same one.  I didn't know no impersonator.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ferrie at the party with Oswald (obscured) per Willie O'Keefe's witness.  Jim, in the present, doesn't feel right about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bows his head, holding it in his hands, and his wig starts to come off in his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a long silence.  Ferrie, spent, stares at Jim.  He's about to crack, but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes are going again.  Deals... intrigue - thru the tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lou and Jim share a look.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you take a good look at the TV when they had Oswald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs, can't be bothered) Black, black - just give it to me. (takes the fresh coffee from Lou, lights a Camel) Shit.  I'm so exhausted.  My neck is killing me.  I've got cancer.  Had it for years.  I been working with mice, y'know, trying to come up with a cure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dave, can I just ask you this directly?  Did you ever work for the CIA?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) You make it sound like some remote fuckin' experience in ancient history. Man, you never leave the Agency. Once they got you, you're in for life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And Shaw?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shaw's an "untouchable", man - highest clearance.  Shaw, Oswald, the Cubans - all Agency.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about Ruby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jack?  Jack was a pimp.  A bagman in Dallas for the Mob.  He used to run guns to Castro when he was still on our side.  Check out Jack Youngblood. Shit - we almost had Castro.  Then we tried to whack him.  Everybody's flipping sides all the time.  It's fun 'n' games, man fun 'n' games.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about the mob, Dave?  How do they figure in this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're Agency, too.  Don't you get it?  CIA and Mafia together.  Trying to whack out the Beard.  Mutual interests.  They been doing it for years.  There's more to this than you dream.  FBI fucking hates the CIA.  Navy Intelligence got something to do with it too.  Check out "Alan Pope" in Miami.  Jack Youngblood. Bill Harvey.  Colonel Roselli.  The shooter, I hear, was a Dallas cop - the bagman at Ruby's club.  I heard he shot his own partner.  Got that? Check out the rich fucks in Dallas. H.L. Hunt.  He's dirty.  That's all I know.  But the Agency always runs the show.  Check out something called "Mongoose"  Operation Mongoose. Government, Pentagon stuff, they're in charge, but who the fuck pulls whose chain who the fuck knows, fun 'n' games man - check out Southeast Asia - that's the next big number - the heroin trail.  "Oh, what a deadly web we weave when we practice to deceive."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then who killed the President?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh man, why don't you stop.  This is too fuckin' big for you!  Who did Kennedy?  It's a mystery wrapped in a riddle inside an enigma.  Even the shooters don't fuckin' know!  Don't you get it yet?  I can't be talking like this.  They're gonna kill me. I'm gonna die! (he sits down, cracking, sobbing) I don't know what happened.  All I wanted in the world was to be a Catholic priest - live in a monastery, study ancient Latin manuscripts, pray, serve God.  But I had this one terrible, fatal weakness.  They defrocked me.  And then I started to lose everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit!  Forgot to glue this fuckin' rug today.  You know, at one time I even had a full head of hair like everyone else.  And then I lost that. That fuckin' Clay Shaw.  I hate the bastard.  All I got left is in his rotten, bloody hands.  He tipped the newspapers - I know it.  That's how the Agency works.  They use people, chew them up, spit 'em out.  Now it's my turn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (empathetic) Dave, it's going to be okay.  Just talk to us on the record and we'll protect you.  I guarantee it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They'll get to you, too - they'll destroy you... They're untouchable, man... (then) I'm so fucking exhausted I can't see straight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get some rest, Dave, and you'll feel better in the morning.  We'll talk then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, yeah.  But leave me alone for awhile.  I got to make some calls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatever you say, Dave.  I'll be home.  Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A mob scene.  Press from the U.S. and all over the world are filling the corridor.  A French reporter tries to get past the receptionist as Numa passes him with a stack of mail. Also in the hall are many individual citizens who have come to give tips and theories.  One of them is dressed as Satan in a red jump suit with mask, horns, tail and a pitchfork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A mailman, black, comes through lugging three sacks of mail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A camera moves by into the interior offices.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (waving credentials) Paris Match.  We are the largest magazine in all of France.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name is Bulgarinov.  I am with Literaturnaya Gazeta of Moscow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bill Turner.  Ramparts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Coming through, out of the way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know who killed the President? Mr. Garrison is busy but his assistant...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bill escorts him out before he gets the chance to sit down, and then heads for Jim's office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim is reading Newsweek, deeply hurt.  There are newspapers all over his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill has come in during this, completely frazzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Numa pulls a dollar bill from the envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim is moved.  Bill is not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sharon has come in during this, signalling to Jim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sharon shows in Mr. Miller, the Denver oilman.  He's a self- assured, impressive man in his 50's with a western accent, cowboy boots and hat, and a well-cut gabardine suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Numa leaves.  Bill indicates he'd like to sit in.  Jim nods okay.  Miller pays no attention to Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim has gathered together a group of photos of the shooting. Sharon bringing the coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances at the photo but continues on across the room, looking at the pictures on the walls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see a blurry blowup of something behind the picket fence. Miller takes the photo, glances at it and sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim expectant of some help.  A pause.  Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The clock is ticking.  Jim shares a look with Bill.  The cards are on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miller smiles, stands, paces the room.  He continues to ignore Bill completely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans forward across Jim's desk, tapping his manicured index finger on the desk.  Clearly visible to Jim and to us (in a close-up) is Miller's Annapolis ring tapping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim's eyes go to Bill.  He could be wrong, but it's almost as if Bill were going along with the idea now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim leans back, puts his feet up on the corner of the desk, waving them like fans.  Bill waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miller waits.  Bill waits.  Jim comes forward with his reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miller's entire demeanor tightens into a corkscrew of anger and danger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill has a strange reaction - a sudden exhalation of breath as if an entire house of cards were collapsing.  He rises, but Miller goes first, leaving silently.  Once he's gone, Bill turns wearily to Jim.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A man with the demeanor of Julius Caesar walks into Bill's office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (raising arm) Hail!  Et tu, Brutus?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you, too, my friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Numa joins Jim with a stack of new mail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Love a duck!  It takes twenty minutes to get into this office these days. Are we famous or what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Notorious is more like it.  "Jim Garrison is right.  There has been a conspiracy in New Orleans - but it's a plot of Garrison's own making"... and this - "one of the D.A.'s investigators offered an unwilling witness $3000 if only he would fill in the facts of the alleged meeting to plot the death of the President"... How can they write that?  Where did they come up with this? ... (sorting through others)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: charlatan," "power-mad," a "hulking D.A." (New York Post) "Morbid Frolic in New Orleans."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The crazies have taken over the asylum!  It's a zoo out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sensational garbage sells newspapers, Jim.  What else is new?  Look at the thousands of letters you're getting. That's where the heart of the country is. (reads from one) "Dear Mr. Garrison, God bless you for having the courage to go after the murderers of President Kennedy. Please don't stop till they're behind bars.  I am a beautician here in Hannibal, Missouri, and my husband is a janitor in the local high school. We have four kids and not an extra lot of money but we enclose a contribution to help with your work. We are praying for you.  God bless, Judith Hardy, Hannibal, Missouri."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what it's about, boss.  For every lousy article in the press there's a hundred of these.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's fine, Numa, but what about all the people who aren't writing letters.  They're sitting home reading all these lies.  I just heard NBC crew's in town to do a "White Paper" - not on the Kennedy killing, but on us.  One of their top guys, Harry Stoner, is talking to everybody he can find about you, boss...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh Jesus, Stoner!... Why doesn't he call me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bill) What do you want to do, Bill - fold up and close the store?  You sound like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, this is bigger than all of us. We can't try a case in this atmosphere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Miller's been waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (remembering) Oh!  Send him in. (to Numa) Denver oilman wants to support the investigation. (specifically to Bill) Bill, I know what you're thinking, but sometimes when it makes no sense that's exactly when you just gotta stick to it, head down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Welcome, Mr. Miller.  Jim Garrison. Would you care for some coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, thank you, Mr. Garrison.  Your coffee's almost Turkish down here but I could get used to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad you could find time to see me.  I flew down from Denver this morning on my private jet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, your letter indicated you were in he oil business up there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've done quite well in Denver, Mr. Garrison, but I have to admire someone like you - and I have the means to back up what I say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can use all the support we can get.  I think these might interest you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They've been enlarged and show a lot of detail...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Splendid, love to see them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where were you?  Europe, Pacific?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Germany.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were lucky.  I spent three years in the Pacific. (he looks out the blinds at Tulane Avenue) I've never seen an avenue with such a profusion of bail-bonding companies. Why is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nettled by Miller's moving around) I imagine because this is the Criminal District Court Building (showing a photo) This is an enlargement of a potential shooter standing behind the picket fence.  We...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know about that shot.  A terrible tragedy. (Puts the photo back on the desk) How much do you have for carrying on your investigation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you must know, virtually nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many men are working with you on this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Less than you would guess.  Most days two to three assistant D.A.'s. A handful of police investigators.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all you've had all this time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I admire you, Mr. Garrison.  How did you manage to make your way into Guy Banister's operation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was never in he newspapers, Mr. Miller.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to be very frank with you. You've done a great job, an astounding job considering the limited resources available to you.  But the best you can ever hope for is to stir up a lot of confusion.  You're not going to do this country any good, and you're not going to do yourself any good. (he sits back down and looks directly at Jim) You don't belong here.  On this Mickey Mouse street with that cheap strip of bail bond shops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The job manages to keep me pretty busy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nonsense.  You should be in a job where you can make decisions that have impact, affect the world.  Here you're trying to climb up the steep side of Mount Everest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I propose you accept an appointment to the bench in Federal District Court and move into a job worthy of your talent. (he leans back and pauses) Do you have any idea, do you have any conception of how easily such an appointment can be arranged?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what would I have to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop your investigation... it was a magnificent effort but it's over and done with.  The press is already on your behind and that's only the beginning, my boy, only the beginning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long do you think it would take me to be appointed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling, thinking Jim is hooked) Well, ordinarily these things take a long time.  But in your case, with your record it can be expedited - easily.  I guarantee it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you, Mr. Miller? (no answer - just the sound of the overhead fan) You see that helmet over there? (the Nazi helmet with a bullet hole on his desk) I picked that up at the Dachau concentration camp when we liberated it in 1945.  It was the most horrifying sight I've ever seen, Mr. Miller.  Pyramids of decaying, stinking bones and skin one on top of the other.  I don't enjoy looking at that swastika every day, Mr. Miller, but I keep it there to remind me of what can happen when a country turns from free democratic principles to Fascism, when a few madmen turn human beings into digits and millions sit in silence and do nothing about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Miller, you and I have met under a great misunderstanding.  I haven't the remotest interest in becoming a Federal Judge.  And nothing is going to keep me from going ahead with my investigation of John Kennedy's murder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bill, Mr. Miller and I have finished our conversation.  Would you show him out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those bastards!  That's proof enough right there of what we're up against. The whole goddamn Federal Government, Bill!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, they offered you the carrot, and you turned it down... you know what's coming next, don't you, boss?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: "FERRIE CALLS GARRISON PROBE A WITCH HUNT

direction.raw_text: The staff is assembled.  We see the headline in the Times- Picayune, which says: "FERRIE CALLS GARRISON PROBE A WITCH HUNT."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Numa rushes in with a young investigator, Williams - displaying a miniature microphone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Numa makes violent signals to shut up - not to talk - sticking the microphone in front of Jim.  Williams searches the walls for the bug.  Numa signals everyone outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The whole staff from the conference room reacts.  Jim looks stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sharon has been standing there trying to get Lou's attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lou goes to the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone laughs, but the camera goes to the look of shock on Lou's face as he holds the receiver.  They all look over at him; feeling the bad news before they hear it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim's look says "There goes the case."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Boss, I tell you something or somebody is putting tremendous heat on David Ferrie.  If we sit on our behinds any longer, I don't think the guy's going to hold on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (raps the newspaper) Look at this bullshit!  He keeps changing what he says.  We can't possibly call him to a Grand Jury.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Susie, watch the language, would you please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My instinct is that Ferrie is going to keep on deteriorating, and we'll end up getting more out of him when he finally cracks.  If we call him now, he might freeze up and we could lose the best shot we've ever had.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't get it, guys - he can't go down any further.  We got to protect him full time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rises, looks at his watch) I have a plane to catch... going to Washington.  An interesting lead, says he's closely connected to these events, but he won't come down here... I know what you're going through with Ferrie, Lou.  We'll talk tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm onto Ferrie's Cuban paymaster, Eladio del Valle, in Miami.  I gotta get him in, boss.  I need more men - I can't even pull the teams to watch Ferrie... This is our case!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Lou) You just need some sleep, Lou.  It won't look so bad when...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The staff comes out into the office with Him, disturbed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell is...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Williams found this in your office... We think the conference room is also bugged.  And maybe the phones.  The whole place needs debugging.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't believe it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bugging the District Attorney's office of New Orleans!  It's outrageous!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's urgent for you, Mr. Ivon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, believe what you want, boss, but we got to be more careful.  All these new volunteers, any one of them could be...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, you handle it, Numa.  I don't have time for this nonsense. (to the hidden mikes loudly) We've obviously got the bastards worried now.  I'm going to Washington.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dave Ferrie's dead.  The body was found at his apartment two hours ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jim and his staff storm into the area, which is cordoned off by police. Members of the press are all over, yelling questions at Jim.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to chief police officer) This case is in our jurisdiction.  I don't want anyone from a Federal agency in here without an explicit Federal court order.  You got that, Hank? (Hank looks at him weirdly)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was Ferrie murdered, Mr. Garrison? Do you have any leads?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The apartment is filthy and sinister.  Hundreds of mice squeal in their cages, upset by the invasion of men and light. Nothing seems to have been washed in years.  There is an accumulation of furniture, college pennants, photos of young boys in training, books everywhere, ammunition, guns, a piano, maps, fake college degrees on the walls.  Ferrie's naked body lies on the couch with a sheet over it.  He is unwigged, his eyebrows unpainted, false teeth next to him.  Jim studies the corpse as the coroner comes alongside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim picks several empty, capless medicine bottles on a table next to the sofa and looks at them.  Lou and Bill come over with a typed suicide note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The words from the note hang there weirdly, as Jim paces on into the apartment, one of them medicine bottles in his hand. The music grows, and a sinister feel of danger and death pervades the atmosphere.  Then the sounds drop away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's it look like, Nick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't see any violence, Jim.  Heart attack, maybe an aneurysm.  Looks like natural causes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's addressed to no one and no signature.  "To leave this life is, for me, a sweet prospect.  I find nothing in it that is desirable and on the other hand, everything that is loathsome."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pretty flowery for Dave Ferrie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jim hands Lou the medicine bottle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Proloid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I took it once for a low thyroid condition... (he walks away) It raises the metabolism, Lou. (pause) Did David Ferrie strike you as the kind of person who had a low metabolism?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd say the opposite - hypertension.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: T IN FERRIE'S APARTMENT Jim runs an eye through Dave's closet, cluttered with shabby jackets. His eye falls on a neat but faded lace and satin, some sort of garment of priestly origin, he takes it in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susie Cox walks in, a new message written on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim's mood darkens, and he heads back into the living room as Ferrie's corpse is being trundled out the door.  The sickness is everywhere; an oppressive mood.  Bill comes up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim, feeling ill, wanting to leave, stops the coroner before he exits...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ferrie was the only one to express some kind of remorse about this whole thing.  I think it got him killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boss, we just got bad news from Miami. They found Ferrie's Cuban friend - Eladio del Valle - this morning, hacked to death with a machete in his car.  He was tortured, shot in the heart at point-blank range and his skull was split open with an axe...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus - if that ain't the Devil's piss!  Those bastards!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Found another note, same thing, no name, no signature.  "When you receive this, I will be quite dead, so no answer will be possible.  I offered you love.  All I got in return in the end was a kick in the teeth."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, they must've been hard pressed to come up with that one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gives the coroner the empty bottle) Nick, what would happen if a man suffering from hypertension were to take an entire bottle of Proloid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'd die pretty quick, either a heart storm or a ruptured blood vessel in the brain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you ascertain if there's Proloid in his system?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not in a routine autopsy, but if we looked at the spinal fluid, there might be a high level of iodine, but it's difficult to know.  Whatcha thinkin', Jim?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it doesn't make sense, Nick - he was afraid of dying, then he kills himself in a way that leaves no trace, but he leaves two unsigned suicide notes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs, skeptical) If it's a suicide, I seen weirder, Jim. (exits)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The fact is he's gone, chief, and so's our case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not unless we go for Shaw now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With whose testimony?  Willie O'Keefe? A male prostitute.  Jack Martini?  A drunk?  Vernon Bundy?  A dope fiend. Shaw's got respect, the newspaper editors, the American Bar Association - they're not...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid I'm with Bill on this one.  We haven't got the goods yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We wait, Shaw's gonna get whacked. Oswald, Ruby, Ferrie, del Valle, Banister, Bowers...  how many corpses you lawyers gotta see to figure out what's going on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, all right.  Break it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where you going, boss?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, Bill, I just don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Jim, questioned by reporters, gets in his car and leaves, Bill waves goodbye to Lou and walks toward his own car, dejected.  The area is cordoned off and humming with activity. Frank, an FBI man who knows Bill from previous cases, approaches him out of the crowd.  He wears a hat, suit, and tie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This gets Bill's attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill, taken aback, listens.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: OUTSIDE FERRIE'S APARTMENT THAT SAME NIGHT
result.heading: OUTSIDE FERRIE'S APARTMENT THAT SAME NIGHT

dialogue.raw_text: Bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, where y'at, Frank?  You're wasting your time here.  Big Jim gave strict orders.  No FBI allowed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's you I want to talk to, Bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) Boss would fry me in hog fat if he knew... (motions to car)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting in the car) Your boss got a serious problem, Bill.  Real serious.  We know what's been going on at your office
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Yeah, I guess you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got nothin', Bill.  I'm talking as a friend now.  You're riding on the Titanic.  Time to jump off before you get destroyed along with Garrison.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frank, I don't want to hear it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Senator Long set your boss up, my friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who do you think fed him that information?  Garrison's going down. We're talking your career here, Bill, your life.  You're a young guy... we know you're working that Castro thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm not...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, you are.  Look we know Oswald didn't pull that trigger.  Castro did.  But if that comes out, there's gonna be a war, boy - millions of people are gonna die.  That's a hell of a lot more important than Jim Garrison. (suddenly) Goddammit, look at me when I talk to you!  You're too goddamn self- opinionated, now shut up.  If you got a brain in that thick skull of yours, listen to me.  Listen real hard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .C. - PARK(1967) Jim walks down from the Lincoln Memorial, where he is met unobtrusively by a military man in his 50's in casual clothing, hat on his head, an erect posture.  They walk towards the Mall, with the Capitol building looming in the background. X Jim Garrison?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man doesn't answer.  Jim, after his meeting with Miller and loss of Ferrie, is testy and suspicious. X I could give you a false name, but I won't.  Just call me X.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something about his manner speaks of authority, knowledge, and above all, old-fashioned honesty - the eyes looking at you straight on.  He indicates a bench. X Everything I'm going to tell you is classified top secret... (significant look) I was a soldier, Mr. Garrison.  Two wars.  I was one of those secret guys in the Pentagon that supplies the military hardware - the planes, bullets, rifles - for what we call "black operations" - "black ops", assassinations, coup d'etats, rigging elections, propoganda, psych warfare and so forth.  World War II - Rumania, Greece, Yugoslavia, I helped take the Nazi intelligence apparatus out to help us fight the Communists. Italy '48 stealing elections, France '49 breaking strikes - we overthrew Quirino in the Philippines, Arbenz in Guatemala, Mossadegh in Iran. Vietnam in '54, Indonesia '58, Tibet '59 we got the Dalai Lama out - we were good, very good.  Then we got into the Cuban thing.  Not so good. Set up all the bases for the invasion supposed to take place in October '62.  Khrushchev sent the missiles to resist the invasion, Kennedy refused to invade and we were standing out there with our dicks in the wind. Lot of pissed-off people, Mr. Garrison, you understand?  I'll come to that later... I spent much of September '63 working on the Kennedy plan for getting all U.S.  personnel out of Vietnam by the end of '65. This plan was one of the strongest and most important papers issued from the Kennedy White House.  Our first 1,000 troops were ordered home for Christmas.  Tensions were high. In November '63, one week after the murder of Vietnamese President Diem in Saigon, and two weeks before the assassination of our President...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. X (shakes hands) I'm glad you came.  I'm sorry about the precautions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I just hope it was worth my while, Mr...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've already been warned by the Agency, Mr. Whoever.  If this is another type of threat, I don't... X I'm not with the Agency, Mr. Garrison, and I assume if you've come this far, what I have to say interests you.  But I'm not going to name names, or tell you who or what I represent. Except to say - you're close, you're closer than you think...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the Pentagon offices in 1963.  X strides down a busy hall and into the offices of one of his superiors, Major General Y, a lean, cold warrior, battlefield handsome, civilian clothes, and several advisors.  There's a U.S. flag on the wall.  The status of Y is only clear by the sing on the desk, the name blocked by a passing figure. X ...a strange thing happened.  I was sent by my superior officer, call him Y, to the South Pole as the military escort for a group of international VIP's.  This trip had nothing to do with my nine years of work in Special Operations.  It was sort of a "paid vacation". We hear vague ad-lib mutterings on the soundtrack indicating a friendly atmosphere, and we see stock footage of a C-130 transport flying to Antarctica and ice floes on the surface of the sea. Then, at a New Zealand airport, we see X, in a uniform, at a newsstand reading of Kennedy's assassination.  The banner headline of an "Extra" edition of The Christchurch Star screams out "KENNEDY SHOT DEAD." X It wasn't until I was on my way back in New Zealand that I read of the President's murder.  That was 2 in the afternoon the next day New Zealand time, but already the papers had the entire history of an unknown 24-year- old man, Oswald - a studio picture, detailed biographical data, Russian information - and were pretty sure of the fact he'd killed the President alone, although it took them four more hours to charge him with the murder in Texas.  It felt as if, well, a cover story was being put out like we would in a black op. Back at the Pentagon office, we see X returning and meeting Y.  The atmosphere is cordial, but Y is slightly different from before - more harried, more nervous.  He turns away to light a cigarette, he doesn't want the usual conversation. X Anyway, after I came back I asked myself why was I, the chief of special ops, selected to travel to the South Pole at that time to do a job that any number of others could have done? One of my routine duties if I had been in Washington would've been to arrange for additional security in Texas.  The Secret Service is relatively small, and by custom the military will augment them.  I checked it out when I got back and sure enough, I found out someone had told the 112th Military Intelligence Group at 4th Army Headquarters at Fort Sam Houston to "stand down" that day, over the protests of the unit Commander, a Colonel Reich... We see an outdoor shot of the Texas Army Headquarters on a day in 1963.  Inside, on the same day, Col. Reich is on the phone, puzzled. X Now this is significant, because it is standard operating procedure, especially in a known hostile city like Dallas, to supplement the Secret Service.  Even if we had not allowed the bubbletop to be removed from the limousine, we'd've put at least 100 to 200 agents on the sidewalks, without question!  There'd already been several attempts on de Gaulle's life in France.  Only a month before in Dallas UN Ambassador Adlai Stevenson had been spit on and hit. We'd have arrived days ahead of time, studied the route, checked all the buildings... We never would've allowed all those wide-open empty windows overlooking Dealey... never...  We would have had our own snipers covering the area.  The moment a window went up they'd have been on the radio.  We would've been watching the crowds - packages, rolled up newspapers, a coat over an arm, never would have let a man open an umbrella along the way - Never would've allowed that limousine to slow down to 10 miles per hour, much less take that unusual curve at Houston and Elm.  You would have felt an Army presence in the streets that day, but none of this happened.  It was a violation of the most basic protection codes we have. And it is the best indication of a massive plot in Dallas.  Who could have best done that?  People in my business, Mr. Garrison.  People like my superior officer could've told Col. Reich, "Look - we have another unit coming from so and so providing security.  You'll stand down."  That day, in fact, there were some individual Army Intelligence people in Dallas and I'm still trying to figure out who and why.  But they weren't protecting the client.  One of them, by the way, was caught in the Book Depository after police sealed it off. In Dealey Plaza, 1963, we see an Army intelligence man taking a shot with a Minolta camera. X Army Intell had a "Harvey Lee Oswald" on file, but all those files have been destroyed.  Many strange things were happening that day, and Lee Harvey Oswald had nothing to do with them.  We had the entire Cabinet on a trip to the Far East.  We had a third of a combat division returning from Germany in the air above the United States at the time of the shooting, and at 12:34 P.M., the entire telephone system went dead in Washington for a solid hour, and on the plane back to Washington, word was radioed from the White House Situation Room to Lyndon Johnson that one individual performed the assassination.  Does that sound like a bunch of coincidences to you, Mr. Garrison?  Not for one moment.  The cabinet was out of the country to get their perception out of the way. The troops were in the air for possible riot control.  The phones didn't work to keep the wrong stories from spreading if anything went wrong with the plan.  Nothing was left to chance.  I bet you there were even backup teams and cars on the other side of the underpass in the event that Kennedy got through wounded. They would have moved in with vehicles like they did with de Gaulle.  He could not be allowed to escape alive. The camera is on Jim, listening.  This information is much greater than he ever envisioned, and he is stunned.  X pauses. X I never though things were the same after that.  Vietnam started for real.  There was an air of, I don't know, make-believe in the Pentagon and the CIA.  Those of us who'd been in secret ops since the beginning knew the Warren Commission was fiction, but there was something... deeper, uglier.  And I knew Allen Dulles very well.  I briefed him many a time in his house.  He was also General Y's benefactor.  But for the life of me I still can't figure out why Dulles was appointed to investigate Kennedy's death.  The man who had fired him.  I got out in '64.  I retired from the U.S. Air Force.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I never realized Kennedy was so dangerous to the establishment.  Is that why? X (chuckles) That's the real question, isn't it - "Why?" - the "how" is just "scenery" for the suckers...  Oswald, Ruby, Cuba, Mafia, it keeps people guessing like a parlor game, but it prevents them from asking the most important question - Why?  Why was Kennedy killed?  Who benefitted?  Who has the power to cover it up?... You know in '61 right after the Bay of Pigs - very few people know about this - I participated in drawing up National Security Action Memos 55, 56, and 57.  These are crucial documents, classified top secret, but basically in them Kennedy instructs General Lemnitzer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, that from here on forward...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the Pentagon offices on a day in 1961.  A document is moved by hand into Lemnitzer's office where we see a set of hands holding it while it's read.  There's a look of surprise on Lemnitzer's face. X ... the Joint Chiefs of Staff would be wholly responsible for all covert paramilitary action in peacetime. This basically ended the reign of the CIA - "splintered it", as J.F.K. promised he would, into a "thousand pieces", - and now was ordering the military to help.  This was unprecedented.  I can't tell you the shock waves this sent along the corridors of power in Washington. This and, of course, firing Allen Dulles, Richard Bissell, and General Charles Cabell, all of them sacred cows of Intell since World War II. You got some very upset people here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: flash on the screen - Allen Dulles, sweet- faced, smiling, at the Warren Commission Hearing and visiting Dealey Plaza; General Charles Cabell and Richard Bissell... X Kennedy's directives were never really implemented, because of bureaucratic resistance, but one of the results was that the Cuban operation was turned over to my department as "Operation Mongoose", which meant that people like my superior officer, General Y, took over the Cuban personnel that were being trained to invade Cuba - and the bases like the training camp at Pontchartrain in your home state that were closed down by Kennedy... and that's how the "black ops" people, people like General Y, ended up taking the rules of covert warfare they'd used abroad and brought'em into this country. Now they had the people, the equipment, bases and the motivation... check out an old CIA man, Bill Harvey - ran something called "Executive Action", which carried out foreign assassinations.  Harvey was also involved with the fake defection program that got Oswald into Russia. Check out the Cabell brothers. Interesting links to this case. At Arlington Cemetery on the same day, Jim visits the grave of President Kennedy.  We see the eternal flame.  Jim thinks about what he should do now.  The size of it stuns him.  He is lost, reeling back to the past in his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of Dachau concentration camp: thousands of bodies are piled and bulldozed... And then back to Jim at Arlington Cemetery reliving it... only the enormity of past evil can prepare him to confront present evil.  In a strange way, it reassures him. X ...don't underestimate the budget cuts Kennedy called for in March of '63 either - close to 52 military installations in 25 states, 21 overseas bases, you're talking big money.  You know how many helicopters have been lost in Vietnam?  About three thousand so far.  Who makes them?  Bell Helicopter.  Who owns Bell?  Bell was near bankruptcy when the First National Bank of Boston approached the CIA about developing the helicopter for Indochina usage. How 'bout the f-111 fighters?  General Dynamics in Fort Worth.  Who owns that?  Find out the defense budget since the war began.  $75 going on a hundred billion ... $200 billion'll be spent before it ends.  In 1950 it was $13 billion.  No war, no money. Sometimes I think the organizing principle of any society is for war. The authority of the state over it's people resides in it's war powers. Even Eisenhower - military hero of WWII - warned us about it: "beware the military - industrial complex", he said.  Kennedy wanted to end the Cold War in his second term.  He wanted to call of the moon race in favor of cooperation with the Soviets. He signed a treaty with the Soviets to ban nuclear testing, he refused to invade Cuba in '62, and he set out to withdraw from Vietnam.  But that all ended on November 22, 1963.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the White House, 1963.  Lyndon Johnson is with Henry Cabot Lodge.  We see them as shadowy figures from a distance across the wide room, or near a veranda with a porch and plenty of light.  Johnson, his back to us, talks in a loud, thick Texas drawl (mostly muted) and signs a document. X Only four days after J.F.K. was shot, Lyndon Johnson signed National Security Memo 273, which essentially reversed Kennedy's new withdrawal policy and gave the green light to the covert operations against North Vietnam that provoked the Gulf of Tonkin incident.  In that document lay the Vietnam War. In the park with X, Jim is staggered by all this information. X ceases walking and looks at Jim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim watches this mystery man walking away.  The figure vanishes in the Washington breeze.  Flags flap over some distant memorial to some distant history of the Republic. Jim rises, a decision made.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't... I can't believe it.  They killed him because he wanted to change things.  In our time - in our country? X (shrugging) Kings are killed, Mr. Garrison. Politics is power, nothing more. But don't believe me.  Don't trust me.  Do your own work, your own thinking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The size of this is... beyond me. Testify? X No chance in hell, Mr. Garrison. I'd be arrested and gagged, declared insane and hospitalized... maybe worse.  You, too.  I can only give you background, you got to find the foreground, the little things... Keep digging.  Y'know you're the only person to ever bring a trial in the murder of John Kennedy.  That's important - it's historic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't yet.  I don't have much of a case. X (rising to leave) But you don't have a choice anymore. You've become a significant threat to the national security structure. They would've killed you already, but you got a lot of light on you. Instead, they're gonna destroy your credibility; they already have in many circles in this town.  You're some kinda ego-crazed southern caricature to many folks.  Be honest - the best chance you got is come up with a case, something, anything, make arrests, stir the shitstorm. You gotta hope to reach a point of critical mass where other people will come forward and the government will crack.  Remember, fundamentally people are suckers for the truth, and the truth is on your side, 'bubba. I hope you get a break...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NEW ORLEANS(1967) Jim, Lou, Al, Numa and several policemen stand at the door as Clay Shaw comes to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The voice dropping away as the devastated look on Shaw's face spreads, sickly, undone, his arrogant public composure gone, face now filled with terror, disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The policemen take Shaw while the D.A. staff moves into the carriage house past the butler, Frankie Jenkins.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Shaw, you're under arrest, charged with conspiracy and entering into an agreement with other persons for the specific purpose of committing the crime of murder of President John F. Kennedy in violation of...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...we have a warrant to search the premises.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the bedroom, Numa points out to Jim the hooks screwed into the ceiling.  Al pulls out five whips, several lengths of chain, a black hood and matching black cape.  Dried blood is on one whip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's either a Mardi Gras outfit, or we got the Marquis de Sade here, chief.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't care if he was doing it with giraffes in the zoo, Numa, it's none of our business.  Let's keep this side of it quiet, shall we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you're in a war, boss, you use every weapon you got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not one word.  That's an order.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Shaw is being fingerprinted.  He seems rattled.  Police officers try to get the press under control.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Habighorst notes it as routinely as Shaw seems to have said it, without thinking, possibly preoccupied by thoughts of press people pushing in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Name?  First, middle, last.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clay Lavergne Shaw.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Address?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dauphine, New Orleans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ever use any aliases?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clay Bertrand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Next of kin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Shaw - What do you have to say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see a shot of the exterior of the Justice Department in 1967.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The acting Attorney General speaks to the press.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Shaw was included in our investigation and there was no connection found at all between Shaw and the President's assassin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - CONFERENCE ROOM(1967) Jim confronts a packed room.  Bill is with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see a shot of the Supreme Court building in Washington, D.C. and then a corridor inside the building.  A Chief Justice, looking gray and wise like Earl Warren, moves along the corridor in his black robe delivering his verdict to the press.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In his own office, Jim responds to Justice Warren.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't play with the press.  They shuffle off, quiet, whispering.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If Mr. Shaw had no connection to the assassination, why did the FBI investigate him?  And why, if they did, is his name not mentioned once in the entire 26 volumes of the Warren Report, even it if is to clear his name?  I doubt this Attorney General would qualify for my staff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't think so.  Mr. Garrison has presented absolutely nothing publicly to contradict our findings. As yet I have not heard one fact to refute the Commission determination that Lee Oswald was the lone killer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I congratulate Mr. Shaw.  Most witnesses have to wait for trial before they're allowed to produce sacred cows like the Chief Justice of the land as a character witness, who is of course not under oath and free from the laws of perjury.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Garrison, if what you say is even partly true in this case, you realize you are damaging the credibility of our government, possibly destroying it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me ask you... is a government worth preserving when it lies to the people?  It has become a dangerous country, sir, when you can't trust anyone anymore, when you can't tell the truth.  I say let justice be done, though the heavens fall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Liz and Jim watch, silently devastated, as the NBC "WHITE PAPER" unfolds, attacking Jim.  They can do nothing.  Liz leaves the room, upset.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - NEW ORLEANS(1967) Julia Ann Mercer, 28, looks at Jim with sincere eyes.  Her husband, a prosperous Republican businessman, watches from the corner.  Jim - along with Al - has her testimony in front of him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In the sheriff's report, Mrs. Mercer, it says you were at Dealey Plaza two hours before the assassination but that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, it was about 11 in the morning. I was driving west on Elm Street toward the Triple Underpass, in a rented car - a blue Valiant.  I'll never forget that day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dealey Plaza in 1963.  It's a normal scene - cars, traffic, people starting to arrive for Kennedy's appearance.  We catch a glimpse of Julia Ann Mercer, 23, driving, then stopping traffic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She glances over at the man in the driver's seat.  It's Jack Ruby, wearing a green jacket.  Then she sees a young white man in his mid - 20's, in a gray jacket, brown pants, plaid shirt and wool stocking hat, getting out of the passenger side, going to the rear of the van, opening a tool compartment and removing a package that looks like a rifle wrapped in paper.  He walks up the embankment in the direction of the picket fence.  Ruby looks over and stares at Julia Ann, who turns away and notices three police officers standing near a motorcycle on the overpass bridge.  Her eyes lock with Ruby's a second time and as the traffic moves, she drives on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the Dallas FBI office, Mercer sits at a table looking at photos.  Two FBI agents stand near her showing her photos. She shakes her head "no" several times, until they put a shot of Jack Ruby in front of her.  She holds it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back in the present, Jim continues to question Mercer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim is silent.  Mercer picks up the report and finds the pertinent paragraphs:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...there was quite a bit of traffic and I was stopped alongside a green pickup truck.  It was very noticeable because it was blocking traffic and it was parked with two wheels on the curb.  When I saw the gun, I thought - the Secret Service is not very secret.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The next morning, Saturday, I went to the FBI office and the agents showed me photographs...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I picked out three pictures that looked generally like the driver of the truck and then...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Second Agent) Jack Ruby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about these others?  You said they might be him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They look a little like him.  But no, (holding up the Ruby photo) I'm sure this is the man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you identified him on Saturday, the day before Ruby shot Oswald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.  When I saw him on TV, I was shocked.  I said to my family, "that was the man I saw in the truck."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (skeptical) But you didn't seem nearly so sure in your statement to the Warren Commission.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what bothers me, Mr. Garrison. You see, they've been altered.  My statements...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This says "Mercer could not identify any of the photographs as being identical with the person she had observed slouched over the wheel of a green Ford pickup truck."  That's not true.  I recognized him and I told them so... They also said it was a dark green air conditioning truck, which it was not.  And here... (she goes to another report) ...on the Dallas Sheriff's report. This is really strange.  See that notarized signature on the bottom of each page?  That's not my signature. And there never was any notary present during any of my questioning. (she hands the papers back to Jim) I guess that's all...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Mercer, as a former FBI man, it's difficult to accept this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, but Mr. Garrison, the FBI is just not doing their job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a Republican, Mr. Garrison, and I don't go in for this kind of government bashing, but I must tell you something's not right when they don't even bother to call Julia in front of the Warren Commission.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They didn't call a lot of people, Mr. Mercer.  I think it's safe to say the Warren Report is a work of fiction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a woman of ample proportions and a big, cute Texas face, ex-club singer, meets with Jim and Lou Ivon in a nightclub not unlike Ruby's Carousel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jada and Beverly sit down at the table with Ferrie, Oswald, and Jack, with Jack doing the buying.  It's too loud to hear anything.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Beverly, tell Mr. Garrison about the Carousel club.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Oh yes, I used to go over there a lot to see Jack and especially my friend Jada who danced there.  It was the real swinging spot in town. Everybody came.  Businessmen, politicians from Austin, Lyndon Johnson's friends... Dallas was a slow town back then.  You chewed toothpicks, played dominos, spit and dated policemen.  But Jack's was exciting.  There were always cops there.  Jack liked 'em around, but he used to throw the drunks out himself, 'cause he was kinda a violent- tempered man... it seemed everybody in those days knew Jack was with the Mob.  The cops were "bad" back then - they'd shake you down for the money in your pocket.  They put a lotta people in the cemetery, especially colored people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Beverly, what about Lee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Oh, yeah.  One time I came in, Jack introduces me to these two guys.  He said, "Beverly, this is my friend Lee..." and I didn't catch the other guy's name.  He was a weird-looking guy with those funny little eyebrows. The other guy, Lee, didn't make much of an impression either.  He wasn't good-looking or nuthin', he didn't look like he had any money, and he was in a bad mood, so I didn't pay him much mind.  Well, I might not remember a name, but I always remember a face.  When I saw him tow weeks later on the television, I screamed, "Oh, my God - that's him!  That's Jack's friend!"  I knew right then it had something to do with the Mafia... Well, about a week later, after she told the newspapers she'd met this guy Lee with Jack, Jada disappears off the face of the Earth...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Never knew what happened to her till Herman offered to sell me her wardrobe.  I said, "but Jada's coming back," and I remember the way he smiled... and I knew she was never coming back.
direction.name: direction

The driver had stopped - I don't know what was wrong with that driver.  And then, out of the corner of my eye, I saw this flash of light, in the bushes and that last shot... just ripped his head off, I mean, blood, brains, just blew everything...

I saw this one guy running from the Book Depository towards the railroad tracks.  And that was the same man I saw on TV two days later shooting Oswald.  That was Jack Ruby.  No question about it.

dialogue.raw_text: It was him I was chasing up the Grassy Knoll, thinking our guys had shot back and maybe we got one of them. I don't know what I would have done if I had caught him, but I knew something terrible had happened and somebody had to do something.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I saw a guy shooting from over there.  He was behind that fence. What are you going to do about it?

It was all kinda queer, but it sure felt like two and two was coming up three... and then they took Mary's five snapshots from me, sent them to Washington, and when they returned them weeks later, two of them had the backgrounds mutilated... The only one we saved was in Mary's camera.  I didn't want to go to Washington when the Warren Commission subpoenaed me... so the lawyer come down here and interviewed me at Parkland Hospital.

dialogue.raw_text: He asked me why I thought I was in danger and I said:
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well if they can kill the President, they can certainly get me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That doesn't make sense, Mrs. Hill. We have the man that killed the President.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you don't!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He kept trying to get me to change my story about the shots.  He was getting hot under the collar, and telling the woman not to write when he wanted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, do you want the truth, or just what you want me to say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want the truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The truth is that I heard between four and six shots.  I'm not going to lie for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...you heard echoes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.  I had guns all my life.  I used to go turtle shooting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I realize you're under a great deal of stress .. it's clouded your judgement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) So off the record, he starts talking about my family, and even mentioned my marriage was in trouble like I didn't know it or something.  He got angrier and angrier and then:
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I knew something was crooked as a dog's hind leg, 'cause no one who is just taking a deposition gets that involved and angry... sure enough, when I finally read my testimony as published by the Warren Commission, it was a fabrication from start to finish.

dialogue.raw_text: Are you willing to testify, Mrs. Hill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (without hesitation) Damned right I would.  Somebody's got to tell the truth around here 'cause the Government sure ain't doing it.

You try to hit a moving target at 88 yards through heavy foliage with this cheap 13-dollar sucker, the world's worst shoulder weapon.  No way.  The FBI tried two sets of tests and not one of their sharpshooters could match Oswald's performance.  Not one.  And Oswald was at best a medium shot.  The scope was defective on it, too.  I mean this is the whole essence of the case to me.  The guy couldn't do the shooting.  Nobody could.  And they sold this lemon to the American public.

No... the only reason for waiting to get him on Elm is you got him in a triangulated crossfire.  You got him on a flat low trajectory from the front at the fence there.

They coulda told him anything, either 1) they were going to close down the plotters that day, or 2) they were going to fake an attack on Kennedy to whip up public opinion against Russia or Cuba and reverse his policies - it doesn't really matter what they told him, 'cause he was under orders, he was a foot soldier.
